review:
A well-polished and interesting game with extremely clunky controls, likely abandoned by the developer. First off, this game is VERY punishing - one hit from anything results in instant death (even just falling from too high of a platform) and will send you back to the beginning of the game. This isn't a downside though; many punishing games can be rewarding for skilled players. However, I prefer if the difficulty comes from the gameplay rather than the CONTROLS simply being obtuse. To swing a sword, you press the Jump button (yes, it will also make you jump). To hold something, you have to hold down X the ENTIRE time because if you ever let it go, the item in your hands will be violently flung away from you. Did I mention X is also the Run button? Additionally, there's no pause button whatsoever and the developer has expressed his dislike of them - good luck if anything ever requires your immediate attention in real life. This is a game that does not respect your time.

One thing that really strikes me as unusual is that this game actually has lots of hidden content that 99% of the playerbase will almost never see due to the base games difficulty. It seems like the developer finished the first two chapters and then spent all his time adding optional content behind it, but it feels pointless because only the most dedicated, adderall-infused, diehard gamers will actually manage to see any of it. The Boiler Room? The Colosseum? Seeing the final boss in basketball jersey and dunking on him in a basketball match? All this developer effort spent on things almost nobody will ever experience. It's honestly a shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041937633', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 4411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2685, 'last_played': 1694193468}
review:
TowerClimb is an absolute blast! 

A challenging rogue-like platformer that doesn't pull any punches but is very rewarding once you wrap your head around the level design and resource management. Game does its best not to randomly kill you as most deaths will absolutely have a way to mitigate them; whether that just be by playing well, managing resources to prevent soft lock deaths, or being alert and always have a backup plan for whatever the game throws at you. 

TowerClimb has more than just the standard tower, with many modes and challenges to unlock and complete, and secrets to find. Could easily see myself sinking hundreds of hours into it.

One thing though, is I highly recommend setting up a controller for this game, made it far more enjoyable for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042545967', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1680209739}
review:
I've heard people call it "reverse Spelunky," but that feels overly reductive. In Spelunky, you're going downwards, and gravity is on your side. Here, a decent chunk of the game is just solving the problem of "How do I go up?" because gravity is very much your enemy. The title is pretty literal - you climb a tower, that's the focus of the game. (A real shocker, I know.) Everything else is just a wrench in the gears of your plans to go higher, or another cog to build them with.

It's also a fair bit more technical than most games - there's a few moves that feel like I'm describing fighting game combos. I frequently fall to my death because I pressed the wrong button (RB/X) for Throw Item (LB) or just whiffed the wall-grab because I was too slow or held Sprint (which turns "Throw" into "Hold") or whatever else can go wrong with trying to item-hop around an overhang.

It does have an easy mode, although it's not a huge concession - 3 health instead of 2. I assume it makes a fairly big difference in how far you can go, but it's still no easier to do anything in particular... You just get an extra mulligan on that item-hop where you accidentally took out a crate and lovingly embraced it as you plummeted to your death instead of tossing it into the uncaring abyss to save yourself.

And a word of warning: Don't pet the dogs.

review:
I tried picking this up a few times and never got past the first 30 minutes of gameplay because it seemed pretty repetitive. After finally sitting down and powering through it I discovered an absolute gem.

It's an absurdly difficult game, but mastering the mechanics completely alleviates that. Any time you die, it is 100% your fault. There's a lot to them aswell, from chaining item throws to ascend higher than what a single item throw would let you, to throwing an item and boomerang at the same time to get the extra height and have the boomerang recover the item you used, to the extremely finnicky mobility items that are just as likely to get you killed but let you go dangerously fast.

The true ending took me about 80 hours of grinding to achieve (with a single full run only taking about an hour), which involves starting from the beginning and visiting a few secret areas that each have an item you need to carry to the end of the game. Having to haul these severely limits your inventory space which further compounds the difficulty as you have less room for important tools to help navigate. It was an extremely rewarding journey to go through, and now I'm able to chain multiple wins together back to back.

On top of that, there are some awesome locations to experience that I highly encourage being completely blind on. The game also sports a fantastic soundtrack, a lot of which has made it's way into mine and a few friends playlists.

review:
Truly one of the best games i've ever played, the gratification you get after beating each one of the levels is unmatched in any other roguelike because of the amount of tools you have access to; there's no passive item in this game ,but rather, every single one of them is active and requires you to use all of your platforming skills to overcome the game's challenges, forcing you to become a better player through every death and through experimentation with the incredibly deep systems at play. 
Not to mention the eye candy pixel art, which is best complimented with the awesome soundtrack of the game (my favorite tracks being...well, pretty much every single one, yes they are THAT good, but to get an idea on how good it is, listen to Flex Flash or even the Overly Epic Tutorial Music).
Another big reason why i can't stop coming back to this game is because it oozes atmosphere, it really is unlike anything i've ever played and, again, a big part of that is because of the graphics and kickass soundtrack, which together create this beautiful sinergy of an atmosphere that the only way i can describe, is that it feels like playing while it's raining outside, you have a nice cup of hot cocoa and a blanket and the outside world just ceases to exist the moment you start playing. In short, it's extremely immersive.
I don't want to say a lot more about it because it's best if you just pick it up and discover Towerclimb in its entirety, you owe it to yourself, this game is fantastic.
No seriously, buy it, like, right now.



















Oh and please don't jump out of the tower, trust me it's not a good idea.

review:
[h1] TowerClimb is a mastahpeece [/h1]
I heard about this game from a friend and it has quickly risen up to one of my favorites of all time, It hits the mark on just about every front for me as a gamer. The music is fantastic, it has a retro style but the spritework is great, especially on the death cards. Most important of all the gameplay is some of the most addictive I've ever come across, the mechanics are simple at a first glance but there's many little nuances that can advance your runs to higher levels, you're forced to be resourceful and think even at the earlier levels of the game. Not once did I feel like I was playing something that was padded out to increase the playtime, it took me 100 hours to get my first win and out of hundreds of runs, i can only think of about 3-4 times a death felt unfair. This game has an amazing way of making you want to see more, just break your record even if only by a few feet, discovering the intriguing new areas and new items drove me to keep climbing despite any frustration I may have felt. I'm now pushing 130 hours and still have new things to see in this game, motivation to play and I really have to commend Davioware and Quazi, the developers. It's still baffling to me that only 2 people worked on one of the most fun and addictive games I have ever played in my life, when AAA developers struggle to hold my attention for more than a few months. I'd recommend that any challenge lovers / platformer fans give this game a shot, because if you give TowerClimb the chance it will reward you greatly.
10/10, and that's a score I rarely hand out to games

review:
Está muy bueno, es como el roguelike/roguelite más completo que hay. Lo empecé a jugar porque "era parecido al Spelunky", pero después de jugar tanto me parece muchísimo mejor. Cuanto más jugas mejor se pone el juego, al principio tu único objetivo es "trepar la torre", y las primeras zonas son muy básicas, con 2 o 3 enemigos diferentes, pero cuando ganás el capítulo 1 (Que para ese punto deberías saber bien los controles y como funcionan las cosas), viene el capítulo 2, en el que las zonas son únicas y están perfectamente diseñadas. Además de eso, vas desbloqueando modos de juego que son mucho más difíciles que simplemente "trepar la torre", y tienen mucha más profundidad, decisiones, y básicamente diversión. Como por ejemplo el modo "Centurial trials", que son 100 pisos de zonas aleatorias con eventos aleatorios, o el modo "Colossus", que son 50 rondas de peleas contra enemigos en una especie de coliseo. Además de eso, hay rutas secretas que te dan recompensas y un final alterno que es todo un viaje. Aproximadamente la gente gana el "modo principal" en 80 horas, el progreso es algo muy importante en este juego. Nunca estás parando de progresar, capáz que te quedás estancado a veces pero después de jugar un rato seguís progresando. Y con progreso me refiero a progreso "mental", ya que el juego no tiene mejoras de estadísticas o inventario, simplemente todo el progreso es acordarte y memorizar que cosas son peligrosas, que cosas funcionan, cuales no, y masterizar los controles (Los cuales podría escribir otro testamento entero de por qué son tan buenos). 
En fin, compralo dale que esperás, compralo que vale cada peso, si te gustan los roguelikes de plataformas es, en mi opinión, el mejor pero por mucha diferencia.

review:
This game doesnt have enough variety between playthroughs to justify how unforgiving it is. Such a hardcore challenge should have been a option, not the only option. I wanted a more casual approach, of playing stage by stage instead of having to beat a entire chapter without dying.

I really enjoyed how unique each stage was, but the gratification of beating a stage is instantly ruined by dying on the next stage and having to do everything over again. Having already nearly perfected the first stages and then being forced to redo them while you try to learn the next stage is painful. There is nothing interesting about going through the same stages over and over, theres no unique loot or anything, you are always going with the same stage objects, the same potions and your climbing skills each time.

Usually when i die on a video-game i feel excited to start over, this game, unfortunately just makes me wanna turn it off.

review:
最爱的Roguelite!
这个游戏有着非常高的难度，但是每一次到达新的区域的激动是无法掩饰的，它会促使你继续往上爬，探索更多新的区域，开阔更多的剧情，迎接更多的挑战。
游戏里面有着庞大的物品数据库，这些物品需要谨慎使用并且熟练使用，玩家的背包大小是有限的，所以要合理管理。而且还有强大的合成系统，需要找合成师合成物品，有些看上去还挺有趣的。
在游戏里面，药水是个很重要并且十分救命的资源，所以尽可能使用item来跳跃到更高的高度。
特别在一些关卡，药水的作用自然体现出来，像是item无法够到的地方，Zardo Land左右的滚轮，要是掉下去了能用药水及时救急。
而且游戏还有很多很多细节，隐藏的剧情，在主线之外的那些，同样非常诱人。
不过比较难受的一点就是一些恶心的随机事件和地形的生成，所以这个游戏不仅考验技术，有时候脸也很关键。
除了主线的第一章第二章之外，这个游戏还有100层模式，给具有更强实力的玩家挑战(第二章还没打通，不知道有没有解锁新的模式)
最后我想说一下，强烈推荐这个硬核Roguelite，可惜的就是这个游戏虽然很好，但是全球性的冷门。

author: {'steamid': '76561197965131893', 'num_games_owned': 674, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3336, 'last_played': 1614504531}
review:
Just picked this up again after a bit of a break.  I've been playing it since long, long before it became available on Steam.  Must've ploughed 500+ hours into it by now.  In my opinion, it's one of the best games I've ever played.  

I'm not a great platform gamer, but this appeals to the roguelike fan in me more than anything else.  Every move is a puzzle to solve, and there's always a solution. You just have to find it.  Quickly.  Or die.  Learn, or die.  Or, more accurately, learn AND die.  No one is "completing" this in their first run. 

It's the epitome of pure, concentrated gameplay.  A relatively simple set of basic components with a vast amount of potential and replayability.  Some reviews have complained that it's too hardcore.  Well, not all games are created equal.  Some will lead you by the hand and others will tear off your hand and beat you to death with the soggy stump.  This is of the latter type.  So, what did you learn? Keep your hands to yourself. 

I just noticed there's an "Easy" mode been added at some point.  Not sure what that does, but my recommendation would be to stick with the classic experience and learn to be at peace with dying.  Maybe go play some roguelikes to get you out of the habit of assuming you'll walk through every game you play.  Once that expectation is broken, there''s a whole world of wondrous challenges ahead!

TL;DR - Game hard.  Game good.  Buy game or go bye-bye.

Addendum: one thing it needs is a mute button.  The music is fine, but it's better with it muted and your own music (or whatever) playing.  I even programmed my own mute feature for the game and it was well worth the hassle!

author: {'steamid': '76561197984411633', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 912, 'last_played': 1595126086}
review:
TowerClimb is an unfairly difficult game that uses its roguelike elements to its detriment.

The variance on the difficulty of layout for some stages are completely fucked. You either get a manageable or hundreds of the hell bugs in Volt Cave. You can either pass through the watchers in the Temple well enough or they cluster 5 of them in the same area. And then there's Club Z, where if you get a bad obstacle spawn you CANNOT do anything about it except teleport around it. 

It's ridiculous how much the game punishes you for mistakes. Part 1 is fine, but when you get to Part 2, half the stages contain instant no-revive death pits and you have one chance to traverse some of the obstacles or you will have to waste a bunch of resources to get back up because the only way up is destroyed. At that point there is no point in having extra lives, and sometimes even when you DO, the respawn time and the camera speed is so slow that you will die again before you can get back your bearings.

This game has one of the most arbitrary and poorly done crafting system I've ever seen. It's all wild guessing, there's only a few recipes that are helpful in an average run, and the "best" items are so stupidly rare that there is no chance in hell you will ever craft one, let alone FIND the components for its components.

And don't even get me started on Legend Fragments. What kind of insane person do you have to be to play the game from the beginning, do one of the WORST instant death challenge stages using skills you will be completely untrained for, another RNG stage, beat a enemy gauntlet for a game that did NOT have combat made in mind, AND beat another final boss with 90-120 minutes in between attempts, 5/6 of it requiring you spend at LEAST an hour to get to that part?

Do NOT buy this game if you intend on beating it. There are oldschool roguelikes that are more fair than this game. Fuck this game and fuck you KY.

review:
ENGLISH

Funny as much Cruel, Ruthless, Hard. 
All this is Towerclimb, a roguelike like few. A game that challenges your skills. Fun, hallucinating, competitive. It is an enterprise to try to survive from the tutorial and this will be what drives you to say "why not ... I'll try again!". It is hard to get tired of a title that offers a considerable level of challenge but at the same time so well balanced to make you think that you can, indeed you MUST continue your climb to glory. Because who knows what else is up there that you haven't seen yet.
The gameplay coincides with the structure of the game: challenging. You will use the first hour only to try to SURVIVE THE TUTORIAL, imagine what you can expect starting from the first level which, right from the start, will make you understand that climbing will be a difficult task. Game mechanics are original, innovative and funny and this, for a platform in 2019, is simply upsetting.
The soundtrack is taken care of and adapts perfectly to this title, which has that retrogame flavor that I never regretted, having grown up in '90s with many MS-DOS titles.
The graphics, although it may seems dated, actually INSPIRED by the eight-bit titles of the '80s and '90s, thus being well-kept and fascinating.
If you are looking for something that engages your brain since you start the game, this is the title for you.
And remember: "None has returned".

ITALIANO 

Divertente tanto quanto Crudele, Spietato, Difficile.
Tutto questo è Towerclimb, un roguelike come pochi. Un gioco che sfida le tue capacità. Divertente, allucinante, competitivo. E' un'impresa cercare di sopravvivere fin dal tutorial e sarà proprio questo a spingervi a dire "ma sì... ci provo un'altra volta!". E' arduo stancarsi di un titolo che offre un livello di sfida non indifferente ma al contempo talmente ben bilanciato da farti pensare che puoi, anzi DEVI continuare la tua scalata verso la gloria. Perché chissà cos'altro c'è lassù che ancora non hai visto.
Il gameplay coincide con la struttura del gioco: impegnativo. Impiegherete la prima ora solo a cercare di SOPRAVVIVERE AL TUTORIAL, immaginate cosa può attendervi a partire dal primo livello che, fin da subito, vi farà capire che la scalata sarà un'ardua impresa. Le meccaniche di gioco sono originali, innovative e divertenti e questo, per un platform nel 2019, è qualcosa di sconvolgente.
La colonna sonora è curata e si adegua perfettamente a questo titolo che ha quel sapore retrogame che a me non è mai dispiaciuto, essendo cresciuto negli anni novanta con molti titoli MS-DOS.

review:
A highly challenging roguelike, though you may be able to speedrun it. It's also a marvel in how its aesthetic in its graphics and sound ring strongly of Commodore Amiga paraphernalia, if not some Super Nintendo forays. Really, if you hold nostalgic memories of those two platforms, playing TowerClimb may become somewhat of a joy for you beyond simply playing, and you can expect the required skill to satisfy as well. It's like playing a retro game with apparent modern amenities and music that may remind you of the module music demoscene. It has that MS-DOS charm to it.

If you're looking for a steep challenge with the most minimal handholding ("minimal" because there is a tutorial stage), then you've come to the right game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993995035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 436, 'last_played': 1545664333}
review:
Roguelike plataformero que destila esencia de la SNES por todos sus apartados. La música y sonido tienen ese ambiente 8bit nostálgico que resulta completamente inmersivo. La jugabilidad es muy entretenida con constantes cambios de ritmo, a momentos es un plataformero reflexivo, pensando cada paso con cabeza, y en unos instantes estas escalando freneticamente a 1 cm de ser jodido por rios de lava, o un gusano gigante, etc.. Aunque los controles son poco intuitivos al inicio (para mando me resultan un poco difíciles), resulta relativamente facil de aprender pero dificil de dominar, sobrepasando de forma constante los limites de movimiento que creias que el juego te imponia. El juego continua sorprendiendo con nuevas mecánicas, items, escenarios y secretos a medida que avanzas y vuelves a comenzar una nueva partida. El multiplayer es esencialmente el mismo juego (admite varios jugadores), pero viendo morir de forma miserable a los otros jugadores con menos experiencia mientras tiras de ellos. En resumen es un roguelike plataformero para jugar una partida de vez en cuando e ir mejorando con el tiempo, manteniendose fresco en cada nueva partida y dejando momentazos en tu memoria frecuentemente.

En general no me suelo molestar en escribir más de una linea en las steam review, pero dado que se trata de una joya oculta en steam, creo que esta vez lo merece.

지금은 챕터 2까지 있고, 제작자가 트위터로 챕터 3을 티징하고 있긴 합니다. 근데 저도 챕터 1까지밖에 못 깼어요 orz
저 대신 무지개 맛이 나는 조각 7개를 모아 끝까지 가보시는 분이 있었으면 좋겠습니다. 건투를 빌어요. 

참고) 이 게임은 컨트롤러를 지원하고, 그게 훨씬 편하지만, 게임이 자동으로 컨트롤러 설정을 하지는 않아서 시작 전 컨트롤러를 꽂아두고 마우스로 설정까지 가서 직접 잡아주시면 됩니다.

review: One of the best games I've ever played. OST is great and fits in well for each environment. Difficult while still being fair. Haven't seen any game breaking bugs for all the times I've played the game. Multiple stages to go through that are randomly generated, which is great for replayability but not for speedrunning as it'd be dependant on being extremely lucky. Some items feel completely useless though such as the wands. Dislike how post-beta the game forced you to use a jump berry to stop sliding. In the older version, you could press the jump button while on a wall and you'd stop sliding without using the jump berry. That is, unless if you're holding the up arrow key, which objectively felt way more better and didn't result in a forced jump and a wasted berry. author: {'steamid': '76561198058745611', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 27524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22074, 'last_played': 1711062410}
review:
It's hard to write a review for one of your favorite games of all time. It doesn't help that said game is incredibly overlooked. Harder yet it becomes when you try to avoid spoilers so any potential players can discover everything for themselves. I think the developers share this sentiment, which I believe really hurts this game's discovery, for better or worse. How do you even begin? What do you mention to make sure as many people as possible give this textbook example of a hidden gem a shot instead of scrolling past it? At the end of the day, I think it's just something you have to experience. Something you have to stick through to the end despite all odds.

And yes, you will die, a lot. Of course, that can be said about a lot of indie platformers. What matters here is that each death is accompanied by some revelation, helping you save a few more resources, maybe get a few floors further each time. TowerClimb has a seemingly infinite amount of little nuances and interactions of different mechanics. "What, I can stand on spears? I jump higher if I touch a wasp? Fish are distracted by meat? I can safely hold onto these mines? I can store these grenades for later?" I can promise you that you'll still be discovering things 400 hours in like I am. TowerClimb offers such a sense of progression through skill alone. Check out the death log and notice that the trend of your deaths is getting higher, and higher up the tower.

This game has such an incredible hook that I haven't seen any other game accomplish with just music, atmosphere, and world design. With each new area or secret you discover, your mind will be blown trying to imagine how these developers composed another song of THAT quality, designed another unique setting, mechanic, enemy, item, the list goes on. You could maybe compare the music and artstyle to some of this game's SNES inspirations, but I think that robs it of the incredibly unique identity this game has earned for itself. The pixel art style may seem generic at first, but as you climb higher you'll realize it's truly full of heart and soul and crafts a perfect atmosphere that complements every other element of the game. And honestly, taking this game's music alone, I'm surprised its not a mainstream indie game. By the end you'll be feeling rightfully upset that Davio and Quazi don't receive more recognition for their talent.

All of these elements combined together result in a game that inspires such a great sense of discovery, one that few games truly offer. When you play it, you almost feel like some otherworldly force is commanding you to get just a bit higher. If you can reach the top, I promise this game will have found a permanent place in your heart. Find out why I and many others have been waiting impatiently for Chapter 3 for... coming up on 7 years now. Join us in that wait knowing few other developers can create what Davioware and Quazi have with TowerClimb.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003146259', 'num_games_owned': 1543, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 6130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1997, 'last_played': 1682071580}
review: An absolute masterpiece with endless replayability. Easy to learn but very difficult to master. Each stage of the tower, as one climbs higher, offers new challenges and obstacles; fighting enemies and even puzzle elements. The addition of cute-but-gross unique collectable death art-cards, and a log-graph showing all your attempts gives it a rewarding sense of progression. The spooky art/environments and the unforgettable soundtrack complete the picture. Like a beaten dog, it's a game I always return to no matter how many times it completely wrecks me. Not for the casual player, but for someone looking for a unique challenge unlike anything else, it's a must-play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983239974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1524604646}
review:
I love the look of this game but it has two major flaws that make it frustrating and unfun.  Firstly there's the level generation--some developers use "procedural generation" as an excuse to just dump a bunch of bad levels on you and this is one of them.  It is quite, quite frequent that you receive areas you simply cannot pass without using your very limited stock of items and you cannot easily restock those when they're gone.  

The other flaw, the one that really ended my interest, is the control scheme.  It's overly finicky and designed to make your life difficult.  Using items is an enormous pain since the default action is always to hurl it away as hard as possible which is awkward when you're generally on small ledges.  To swing a sword, you have to jump.  What?  That's of course on the one run in ten where you even find a sword.  You also must keep pressing in the direction of whatever surface you are climbing at all times or your character will immediately let go and usually die for the sin of not holding up hard enough.  There are items that grant you a temporary double jump aura, activated by jumping again while in the air, but the game frequently interprets a single jump press as two and wastes the aura.  

Oh, and in a game about carefully making your way up an endless tower, occasionally the levels fill with lava that rises at the same speed you can climb.  Good luck with that.

review: First Impressions: I was really excited about this game after I saw it compared favorably with Spelunky (one of my all time favorites). However, after playing the first couple levels I felt more frustration than fun. When you die in Spelunky it is almost always your fault; each death makes sense within the systems of the game. Towerclimb feels random and unfair (and this is coming from someone who loves difficult platformers), to the point that I didn't really feel any desire to continue playing. The control scheme is inaccurate, and the pixelated graphics make it hard to discern hazards and items. Often, you spawn into a level with upward gaps that force you to dip into your limited potion supply. This would be akin to Spelunky placing you in a level where the exit is blocked, requiring a bomb to pass. I'll probably try Towerclimb again, and will change the review if necessary, but for now I don't find that this game fits my expectations.

review:
Surprisingly in-depth and entertaining, TowerClimb stands up there with the likes of some of my favorite Roguelike/Roguelite games in the genre. Even after several hours of gameplay, I can safely say that I've only just begun to scratch the surface of what this game has to offer: a distinguishing feature of my favorites of the genre such as Crypt of the Necrodancer, Don't Starve, and Nuclear Throne. 

What gets me is how this title managed to fly under the radar for the most part; heck, even Flinthook received more attention than TowerClimb, and I would consider TowerClimb to be vastly superior to Flinthook! If you are a fan of the genre, then I can safely say that you'll not regret purchasing this title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049701314', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 935, 'last_played': 1589786010}
review:
This game is truly amazing. The level designs are tricky in the best possible way with unique mechanics in every area. Lots of items to toy around with to use in various situations. Sometimes it can feel like the random aspect of the game can cheat you into completely impossible situations, but the extremely useful items do a good job at balancing this, Plus it feels amazing if you do end up making it through with some insane jumps or creative item use. On top of all that it has phenomenal music and art unique to every area that creates overwhelming feelings of adventure, acension, and discovery  that are only hightened by the high tension in the gameplay as you reach new areas and climb the tower.

Don't feel bad if you need to play on easy mode. It will still be extremely difficult, but oh so satisfying when you finally beat your highest climb record or make it to a new area.

I'm 13 hours in and have barely climbed my way into chapter 2 by playing off and on. I'm still learning new things about the game's mechanics and discovering new areas. I think the insane difficulty is what keeps me from finsihing this game just all in one go, which I don't think is a bad thing personally. The climb to the top will be a slow process where I will cherish every moment of satisfaction and discovery because I love this game so goddamn much. author: {'steamid': '76561198114517331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 12142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7916, 'last_played': 1703523894}
review:
I wasn't planning on writing a review for this game until after I beat it, but someone raised the great point that I could edit it at a later date and here I am.

First off, if you're buying the game without much prior knowledge of it, either ask someone who previously played it for advice or look up the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=595709855] community guide, [/url] because the in-game tutorial kind of stinks.

Onward to my next point: this is the best platformer, and maybe even general game, I have ever played. The main gameplay loop consists of entering the tower, climbing as high as you can get, dying from [b] your own [/b] mistakes, and starting again with whatever newfound knowledge and experience you have.

What makes this work so well is how tangible your progress through the tower feels. At any point on your journey, you will find yourself in a completely different environment than the one from the one half an hour ago, giving the tower a layered feel as you make your way to the top, and a feeling of true accomplishment with every conquered area. This is accompanied by fantastic pixel art and amazing sound design, not to mention the beautiful soundtrack. 

The gameplay is in a league of its own. The developers realize very well that less is more, and so the gameplay can be entirely captured in running, jumping, climbing, and throwing or using items. The controls serve this gameplay near perfectly, except for the rare instances where you have to interact with vines (vines are not your friends). A complaint I have seen often is that this game's controls make no sense, and I frankly have to question whether whoever says this gave themselves a chance to even learn how to use them.

The design of this game will never cheat you. Your enemies in the game are the environments of the tower and the creatures residing in them. Every single one of the hazards will kill you almost instantly, but their behaviour and rules are clearly telegraphed no matter what. Whenever you die, it's because [b] you [/b] made a mistake, and the game punished you accordingly.

To summarize, this is a beautiful, well designed and, most importantly, fun game which has lasted me almost 150 hours so far, and I have yet to finish even the core game as of writing this review. If you pick this game up, or are even slightly interested in it, I recommend checking out the game's [url=https://discord.gg/82TQnWy] discord server, [/url] a dedicated and active community of helpful TowerClimb players who are always up to the task of answering your questions about the game or just having a chat about whatever.

EDIT 1: Spelling and grammar.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994899901', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 21612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7730, 'last_played': 1680730774}
review:
Лучший роглайт платформер.
Вы карабкаетесь вверх по башне, стараясь избегать при этом врагов и ловушек. Врагов убивать не обязательно, и у вас по дефолту даже нет оружия, если вы его не найдете в сундуке или не скрафтите. Каждая ситуация как пазл, и решений может быть несколько. Вы можете сыграть сейфово, просто потратив джамп пот, чтобы преодолеть сложное место. Или проявить скилл и пройти, не тратя ресурсов. Или вернуться и пойти другим маршрутом. Уровни рандомизированы, так что ситуации каждый раз разные.
Игра состоит из разных тематических зон, меняющихся каждые 3 этажа (как правило). Каждая имеет свой дизайн, музыку, врагов и ловушки. Геймплей радикально отличается в большинстве из них.
На основную игру у меня ушло 100 часов. Потом нужно найти все секретки и пройти всю игру за раз, чтобы получить секретную концовку, как я полагаю. Потом centurial trials, более рандомизированный режим, в котором смешиваются элементы из разных зон и добавляются некоторые новые, намного сложнее основной игры. Контента в этой игре на сотни часов.
Вообще, исследование - большая часть игры, в ней много секреток, и намного интереснее играть без спойлеров.
Музыка и атмосфера великолепны, художественный дизайн хорош, хотя разрешение могло быть повыше (240х160).
Игра создана двумя братьями, и говорят, что они делают третью главу, за что им большой респект.
В общем, если вам нравится этот жанр и вы не против начинать с начала сотни раз, то 349 рублей за эту игру - это грабеж.

review:
This game contains so much content for a seemingly linear platformer.

Let me start by saying this game is very challenging, between getting a comfortable feel for the game's really unique platform mechanics (such as using a thrown item to give extra jump height), and the mysterious creatures and events that you will encounter on your way to the top.

However, if you want a game that will drive your sense of discovery, and has the right difficulty curve to match your ever-growing skills, this game is a steal. It doesn't take long to get familiar with the controls, and they'll improve over time if you just explore what is possible from other players who have videos. I've been playing a lot of the bonus game modes that you unlock by simply playing the main game, and it's remarkable how much there is to explore in the main story, and with all the things you unlock from playing the main story.

Long story short, the music is great and original, the mechanics are unique and fun once you discover all the items that can be found, and you will get your money's worth. I've made 20 hours of playtime account for 1 dollar spent on this game when writing this, and the return on investment will only continue to grow since reading this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040295426', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1553962886}
review:
I struggled to decide between yes and no. It's a good game, seriously. But it has a very limited audience, in my opinion. So statistically speaking it's not for you, hence my "no". If you love super difficult rogue-likes, then you know what to expect already and should get this game.

I love its minimalism. The graphics are simple and readable. The mechanics are simple but run very deep. I'm particularly a fan of the music too! It has this great sense of imminent danger but slow paced, exactly what you would expect of a dangerous climb.

The thing with this game, and so many other rogue likes, is difficulty. If you ever watched a speed runner playing half life or some other game you probably noticed they have this amazing knowledge of the game. They know every exploit there is, every square inch of the game and practiced way more than any reasonable player. I'm sure they had fun doing it but most people are not interested in knowing a game that well. However, while anyone can enjoy half life with only a fraction of all that knowledge and dedication, Tower Climb requires that much as a bare minimum.

I didn't get very far in the game but I did enjoy my time with it. I won't be playing it any more, but since I got it on sale, I think the game pretty much paid itself for 7 hours of gameplay. At full price I would have felt pretty bad for paying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005882918', 'num_games_owned': 787, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 2712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2626, 'last_played': 1526838584}
review:
I can see that this game is pretty addicting, and I would even dare say that this is probably one of the most under rated indie games on steam. However, I would also say that this game isn't for everyone. This game's difficulty level is very high, and is pretty much exclusive towards a hardcore audience. Even on easy, you'll die a lot. Scrubs will get kicked in the teeth here.

The controls, once you get to learn them, are very fluid. The gameplay is great and the music is very reminiscient of super metroid. As you climb the tower, you have to carefully manage your resources, and sometimes even make quick decisions on the fly. This can be both a good and a bad thing. The good, being that it teaches you to "git gud" over time, and the bad, being that you can't pause the game and oftentimes leads you to your death because you cant react quick enough. 

Ok....you can't pause. I know, I kind of got turned off by it too. But each floor is usually very quick, and after beating the level, that's where you're supposed to take your break.  I think the reason why the devs didnt really bother to implement a pause button was to help you improve, but I still think it causes setbacks too, especially when nature calls or you have to answer your telephone, etc. I imagine that having a pause button would actually help the game more than do harm, but that's my opinion.

The other two things I think would make this better would be to add a quick save function and achievements. Having a quick save would be extremely helpful with this game for those who have to leave and come back later. Achievements would also be a great addition too, as this is a very challenging game. To get you an idea of how challenging, there are people on steam who have played over 100 hours and still havent beaten it. So trust me when I say that if this game had achievements, it would give a player great accomplishment in getting them all.

All things considered, with its flaws, I would give the game an 8.5 out of 10. Without them, I can see the game going to a 9 at least. This a very solid platforming title that would give fans of the genre a lot to offer. If you are up for a solid, brutal platformer, I would recommend this game for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198207396029', 'num_games_owned': 171, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 9341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6545, 'last_played': 1698003614}
review:
TowerClimb is a beautiful and deadly game that will punish you for rushing through the game without thinking your every decision through.  The simple graphics combined with the huge worlds and massive amount of content make this game one you would spend hours on even if you have already finished it.  Just like Spelunky, it's a simple, yet brutal game that will destroy you countless times in the beginning, but once you conquer it and beat that final boss, nothing matches that feeling, and I mean NOTHING.  The mechanics in the game only make it better, from item-hopping, to using swords, and Metal Gear-like stealth action gives you even more reason to play it.  Not only that, but the music is gorgeous, and always fitting the environments.  I always find myself replaying Chapter 1 just for the Ruins music, and the amazing ice environments.  

To sum it all up, TowerClimb is a beautiful game that will beat the shit out of you for a while, but when you overcome it, the ecstasy will last forever (probably).  The music, mechanics, and environments only make it more memorable, and investing hundreds of hours into it (as I have) will feel enjoyable instead of painful.  Buy this game, you really won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989198125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 63125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48161, 'last_played': 1707662616}
review:
Towerclimb is one of my favorite video games, I have beaten it almost at a 100% and I still find enjoyment out of it. 
That said, the game is probably the hardest game out of any that I've played.

TC is, of course, about climbing a tower and getting to new places, but at the core of it all is mastery of the controls, fine tuning of your muscle memory and the art of not panicking. Things are never made easy, every accomplishment is 100% your own, making it that much more rewarding.

Besides all of this, TC has a killer soundtrack, one of a kind mechanics and surprises at every turn (stay unspoiled!). There's so much more in there that may seem at first glance. 

If you are not intimidated by the difficulty and you get satisfaction out of purely getting good at a game, definitely check it out!

author: {'steamid': '76561197996152888', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1420, 'last_played': 1536682816}
review:
Let me try to be a voice of dissent amongst the overwhelmingly positive reviews for this game. 

Tl;dr This game is good. It may even be amazing. But it is FAR too hardcore to have a broad audience, and for that reason, I must give it a thumbs down. That's the basis for my review at the core, but it's not the only reason. I think you should only buy this game if you are the most dedicated of roguelike players with your own personal high mechanical skill cap and are a junkie for Dark Souls to infinity levels of punishment. If you're not, then there is no world where this game is for you. This is not an Enter the Gungeon, Binding of Isaac, Rogue Legacy, or Don't Starve. Buy it, test it, but don't be afraid to get a refund from Steam and don't let yourself feel like this game "beat" you. This game requires religious amounts of dedication to learning its ins and outs along with the most stringent of mechanical prowess to get satisfaction from what you put in. 

PROS

I loved a lot about this game, and I think it does yield a decent return on effort put in (if you can make it that far). That all, however, is not the aim of my review. If you want positives about the game, I suggest looking at the positive reviews. It's got an overall positive rating for a reason. I think that's completely justified, but I can also assume that it doesn't have a very large owner base either. 

CONS

What TowerClimb copiously offers in hardcore rogue-like platforming it falls short in virtually every other department.

* The pixel art is extremely basic. We're talking like if the Atari took steroids, that's the level of art you're to expect from this game. It's hard to distinguish hazards amongst all the muddy sprites sometimes, and it's just generally not very pretty to look at. Now I know that's a preference thing, but let's be serious about how much the quality of art has evolved in games compared to what's being offered here. There's an option to "depixelize" the games which just turns everything into what appears to be blurry, borderless watercolors. Ironically, making it harder to distinguish the multitude of hazards in the game.

* The controls, while seemingly tight, are not very intuitive and require some relatively strict mechanical input to operate in frequent high stress situations. There are a lot of instances where you have less than a second to react to several incoming hazards. They're nigh unnavigable when you have to use upwards of 3-5 inputs almost instantenously. On top of that, several of the buttons serve dual functions at the same time, further complicating these highly mechanical maneuvers. To put this in perspective with an Xbox controller, to hold any item in your hand, you HAVE to hold down the X button at all times if you want it to be held in your hands. If you DO let go of the X button, your character will hurl the item away from you. The X button incidentally also must be held down to run. Very similar to Super Mario's control scheme. Then, let's say you're holding a sword, you have to press and hold the A button to swing it (with a delay on the lower tier swords). The A button also controls your jumping. That's 4 inputs plus movement controlling 6 functions all while trying to navigate hazards in the environment. Then combine all of that with the fact that you can only hold one item in your hands at once and every item has different uses, you're having to do an intricate dance with your hands to operate within life or death situations that affect whether or not you have to completely start over. Unfortunatley, the way the controls are designed and how they interact with mechanics are entirely intentional, so readjusting them would require a lot of reworking of some of the game mechanics.

* The music is unbearably repetitive. Especially when you'll be spending a good chunk of time going back through the same areas after you die and restart. Now the two big issues with this, 1) There are certain sound cues tied to dangers/events happening around you that fall under "music". Not the worst thing and infrequent, but definitely an issue. 2) There isn't an option to turn off the music in the game. That's pretty basic functionality in my opinion. The workaround is to change the name of the "Music" folder in the game's directory to something else, but I don't feel like I should ever be required to do something like that for something literally every game has. Normally, this wouldn't really be a problem, because it's a tendency of rogue-likes. How often can you listen to the same music while dying over and over and not find it repetitive? But without integrated functionality to mute it, it's worth noting.

* Now this is a HUGE issue for me. I'm talking monumental. There is no way to pause or save the game. I understand it's a roguelike where death and restarting are inevitable, but the sheer length of the "story" makes the ability to save a necessity. Even pausing alone would be far better than not being able to at all. I had to leave my computer running with the game playing for 11 hours one night, so I could pick up where I left off in a run.

* As for variety, there are a slew of different biomes and hazards/enemies over the course of the game's 50 or so floor run, but each biome is divided into three floors and you'll be rerunning those floors a lot. Now I've put 10 hours into the first 4 biomes alone and I can very confidently tell you that there is not much variety within them. You are always the same guy, albeit with a different name and outfit color. There is hardly any equipment variation. I must have picked up nearly a thousand crates and blast berries at this point. The rarest thing I've found is appropriately and plainly named Golden Greaves. The cool, rare items that do exist are extremely hard to obtain or have a very low chance of coming into play, and they're usually one use items. The same 3-5 enemies/hazards are present in each biome. (Outside of a few random chance environmental hazards. Which I assure you, you don't want to encounter.) There are no unlockables or persistence aspects of any form between runs. The only thing there is to unlock are harder challenges. Which is great if you didn't mind the rough pounding the game gave you the first time around.

*SLIGHT SPOILER* there is a slight bit of persistence in the form of one checkpoint halfway through the story. *END SPOILER*


OVERALL

I respect the two brothers who made this game. They clearly have a passion for niche, hardcore gaming, but that doesn't mean they're infallible nor does it mean that their project is perfect. 5 years is a lot of time to pour into something you care about, and I know critcism is hard to stomach especially with the amount of thought I'm sure you've put into every aspect of the game. Working as a two man unit without all the resources of a bigger company or studio can leave you lacking in certain areas and that's fine. Maybe you two don't want to cater to anything less than the hardcore fanbase, and I respect that, too. But it can and will alienate your game from mainstream titles like the ones mentioned at the start of this review.

I've said it already, if you want a PUNISHING, HARDCORE, RAGE-INDUCING rogue-like with TIGHT MECHANICS, then you buy this game right now and you play the everlovingshit out of it, but if you're wary of the purchase, then let this review be a warning to what you'll be stepping into.

Spelunkyのファンです。
Spelunkyでは、ローグライクにおいて頻繁に経験することになる「死」を面白くするゲームデザインがとれらていました。
TowerClimbでは死んだときに死因ごとに用意された「カード」がもらえたり、死んだときのスクリーンショットが矢印付きでログ上で閲覧できたりと、やっぱり死を面白いものとするデザインがとられているように感じました。

また、TowerClimbはプラットフォーマーの中では断トツに操作が意味不明です。
なんで走るボタンで物を掴むの！なんでジャンプボタンで攻撃するの！

ちなみに、たぶんiBuffaloのSFCコントローラだとボタンの数が足りないです。そこは残念。

2時間くらいで3エリア目くらいまで到達しましたが、PVを見るとまだまだ見たことのないものが大量にあるようでワクワクします。
まだ見てないギミックや、聴いてない音楽（音楽いいですよね）、手に入れてないアイテムに巡り合えるのがとても楽しみです。

author: {'steamid': '76561198028113055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 30379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2503, 'last_played': 1694967391}
review:
So....28 hours in..... I've lost track of my death count....

Ever think platformers were too easy??  Think you are too hardcore for a platformer??  This game will open your eyes!  

Towerclimb is a brutal platformer that will punish most small mistakes with death.  That ever present threat of immenant death makes the game really epic and enjoyable.  You can purchase revive potions from shopkeeps to help offset the 'one slip and dead' situation.  The controls are very responsive - and 99% of your deaths will be YOUR fault. (whether from lack of skill, stupid decisions, not using/rationing items properly, etc.)   The music is fantastic.  Each run will tend to have a unique feel that requires different platforming skills.  The game has VERY impressive level randomization - which adds to the replay value significantly.  I'd say its definitely worth buying/playing 100%  

Notes - I've played only with an xbox controller and it plays great
           -  I have a high tolerance for dying a lot and learning my way to victory.  If you're impatient or hate dying, this game is probably not for you, lol.
      -Patience, Focus, strategy, intelligence, determination, raw skill, twitch reflexes.....all of these things will help you in this game and create a rewarding experience.  Even with all of this going for you...you will still die....a lot....really a lot.... 
       -Fairly sure the people that downvoted this game about control issues all gave up after a few hours or didn't play with a gamepad.  The controls admittedly have a learning curve - you have to power through it before you will get very far.
     -I personally didn't read any guides or look up any information on this game until after I got to the top of <redacted>  If you take this route - the game will be more of a punishing slog lol.  If you don't care about looking up information - I highly recommend it, as it will open up a lot of useful items and strategy's that make the game generally more enjoyable and survivable.  If you need game info, I highly recommend Tobash's guide.

-update-

Have made significant progress through trials and tribulations - There's really quite a bit more to do in this game for the ultra hardcore platformer lover.  I'm VERY glad I revisited this title and logged in 100+ hours more.  I've been playing with steams remote play feature - with a friend - which is surprisingly really fun.  (this also opens up a whole world of cooperative platforming mechanics that can be quite satisfying - and entertaining - whether you execute them properly or not :P   )  Expect periodic lag for the connecting player in most cases - but with time, patience, and skill  - it can still be played.    Would make an excellent couch co-op game if there's two hardcore climbers in the same spot.  Have noted that the steam overlay can cause some issues with remote play - also having everyone opt in for steam beta 'can' help 'maybe?'

Have tasted victory in a couple places and there's still more to do.  Really impressed with the amount of endgame content that Quazi crammed into this thing.  It's a labor of love and its awesome!

I can honestly say that this game has been an unforgettable experience.  Amazingly with over 1000 death's, I still enjoyed myself significantly!  (somehow?)

review:
If I have any minor quibbles I would say the game could use a dedicated exit button from the main menu, and it would be nice to have individual volume sliders for sound and music. That aside, this is an incredibly polished game with a great soundtrack and charming visual style. 

The game mechanics are constantly evolving so just as you get good at one set of challenges, you have to adapt to a whole new set of challenges. It's a very rewarding system that keeps you coming back in the hopes of climbing those few extra feet. There is enough gameplay and variability here for well over 100 hours and that is a real achievement. Most importantly, the game is a joy to play. Playing local co-op and sharing the sense of discovery with my brother was great and I thank the developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017042557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 27042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3793, 'last_played': 1710411499}
review:
Croyez-le ou non, Towerclimb est l'un des jeux qui m'aura le plus marqué dans ma vie de joueur.
Seulement, il m'a fallu une vingtaine d'heures pour le comprendre, et tout le reste pour l'apprécier.

C'est à mon sens un joyau rare mais recouvert d'une épaisse couche de pierre :
difficile d'accès voir un brin rebutant au départ, il révèlera toute sa splendeur à ceux qui auront pris la peine d'en gratter la surface. 

Je me lance donc ce long commentaire pour tenter d'expliquer les richesses que possède ce jeu étrange et fascinant, 
et les obstacles qu'ils vous faudra franchir pour pouvoir en profiter ! 


+ NARRATION +
A une époque indéterminée, on incarne l'un après l'autre chaque humain qui tente d'escalader une tour mystérieuse afin d'en percer les secrets. Un scénario simple et très discret, mais c'est surtout l'univers et l'ambiance qui se distinguent :
Towerclimb dégage une atmosphère extrêmement particulière, chargée de mythes, de mystères et de mélancolie.
Je n'avais pas ressenti une ambiance aussi singulière depuis Zelda Majora's Mask ou les jeux de Fumito Ueda, qui possèdent une âme, une personnalité très forte.
Towerclimb fait partie de ces jeux-là.


+ STYLE DE JEU +
C'est un rogue-like platformer façon Spelunky, sauf qu'ici il s'agit de grimper au lieu de descendre...
ce qui est d'autant plus intéressant, car l'ascension est difficile et la crainte de la chute est omniprésente.
On a un petit inventaire pour stocker et utiliser divers objets comme des armes, de l'équipement facilitant l'escalade, 
des potions permettant de sauter plus haut ou de créer une explosion, etc.
On parcourt des niveaux générés aléatoirement mais ayant un thème fixe à chaque fois.
Le jeu est divisé en deux chapitres distincts avec un checkpoint au milieu, bien utile pour s'entraîner.
Le second chapitre est excellent et bien plus créatif que le premier, qui reste plus classique mais très réussi quand même.
Il y a deux boss obligatoires à la fin de chaque chapitre, et le combat final, faites-moi confiance, est vraiment exceptionnel. 


+ GRAPHISMES +
J'étais un peu dubitatif en regardant juste le trailer et les screens, mais une fois immergé dans le jeu manette en main, c'est bien différent. Car dans Towerclimb, le visuel, le rythme du jeu, les musiques, l'ambiance, tous ces éléments communiquent ensemble pour créer une belle atmosphère, cohérente et surprenante. 
Les niveaux sont très variés, avec même certaines thématiques que vous ne retrouverez dans aucun autre jeu de ce genre.
Le style est rétro mais ultra fluide, et il se distingue par une direction artistique chatoyante, très personnelle et singulière. Le rétro n'est clairement pas un cache misère ici. De plus, des FX de lumière étonnants (et de bon goût) viennent moderniser le visuel et dynamiser l'action en permanence.


+ DIFFICULTE +
Towerclimb, c'est l'esprit d'un jeu rétro combiné avec un gameplay nerveux, fluide et moderne.
Difficile et décourageant au début, on se met à maîtriser et à adorer le jeu avec la pratique.
Le challenge est clairement compensé par une réelle courbe de progression hyper gratifiante.
Chaque obstacle semble insurmontable au début, mais avec le recul nous paraîtra bien plus simple à aborder une fois arrivé un peu plus loin. Ce challenge fait partie de la durée de vie du jeu : Comptez une vingtaine d'heures pour maîtriser le chapitre 1, 
et le double pour maîtriser le chapitre 2, qui est d'autant plus dur que fun.


+ GAMEPLAY +
Le gameplay jongle entre des phases nerveuses d'action, d'esquive et de plateforme précise, 
et des temps morts plutôt reposants lorsqu'on est occupé à grimper.
Passé le premier quart du jeu, chaque niveau se renouvelle en adoptant une mécanique différente et unique (notamment dans le chapitre 2). Un niveau où il est interdit de casser le moindre bloc sous peine d'être sanctionné, un autre basé sur le principe d'1, 2, 3, soleil avec des ennemis qui tentent de vous forcer à bouger malgré tout, un autre ne contenant aucun ennemi mais qui est basé sur la seule gestion de votre inventaire, un niveau concentré sinon sur de la plateforme pure et dure... 
Franchement, les idées sont excellentes et variées ! c'est dur au départ, mais également super fun d'apprendre à dompter puis à maîtriser chacune des mécaniques du jeu.


+ COMMANDES +
Il est indispensable de jouer à la manette pour en profiter. 
Les commandes sont très inhabituelles, et on pourrait penser qu'elles sont mal foutues.
En réalité, elles sont précisément adaptées aux mécaniques proposées, et ont été volontairement réfléchies dans le sens du jeu. C'est très rebutant pendant quelques heures, mais si on accepte cette phase d'adaptation et d'apprentissage, 
on se surprendra plus tard à maîtriser le personnage comme jamais, de façon fluide, ultra précise et très agréable.
C'est juste une manière différente d'aborder les commandes, mais il faut simplement le savoir et l'accepter.


+ BANDE SON +
Inattaquable, cette OST de 83 pistes (!) est l'un des très gros points forts de Towerclimb.
Elle colle parfaitement au jeu en renforçant son aura tantôt mystique et mélancolique (on sent les influences de Joe Hisaishi et Koji Kondo, comme en témoignent par exemple "Chapter 1 Ending", ou "Temple of Devotion"), tantôt complètement folle et déjantée, avec une sorte de bitpop cosmique super entraînante (l'incontournable "Flex Flash" et les thèmes du "Final Battle" vous convaincront à coup sûr). Ah, et les FX sonores sont excellents aussi. Franchement ce jeu, c'est un régal pour les oreilles. J'ai d'ailleurs acheté l'OST sur steam, et c'est la seule que je possède !



- DEFAUTS -

> Impossible de mettre le jeu en pause ! Alors ça c'est incompréhensible, je n'ai jamais vu ça ailleurs.
Heureusement qu'il y a de nombreux safe spots pour pouvoir souffler un peu, se gratter le dos, ou commander une pizza.
Mais vous savez quoi, cette bizarrerie renforce étrangement l'immersion du jeu. Car on est vraiment dedans. Mais bon, ça n'excuse pas.

> Même si c'est parfois facultatif, on aimerait pouvoir crafter des items un peu plus souvent.
Le personnage qui nous permet de le faire apparaît peut-être un peu trop rarement.

> Certains points de gameplay, qui vont plus loin que le tutoriel, sont un peu difficiles à découvrir par soi-même.
Je recommande donc fortement, après quelques heures, d'aller faire un tour sur le wiki du jeu et surtout de regarder des vidéos de pro-gamers jouant à Towerclimb (comme Tobash par ex.) pour comprendre certaines astuces et mécaniques fort utiles afin d'aborder le gameplay plus facilement ! C'est ainsi que j'ai pu m'améliorer très rapidement et découvrir tout le potentiel de ce jeu.


* CONCLUSION *

Towerclimb ne s'adresse pas à tous car il peut être difficile d'accès sous certains aspects.
Tout dépend de vos affinités : si vos aimez les rogues-like, l'esprit rétro modernisé par un gameplay fun et nerveux à dompter, avec un challenge élevé mais hyper gratifiant, le tout enrobé d'une atmosphère mystérieuse et singulière... alors n'hésitez pas un seul instant !
Dans tous les cas, Towerclimb est, à mon sens, un jeu exceptionnel.

Bought Catacomb Kids and it ran like garbage on my machine so used the refund to get Towerclimb. It had been on my wishlist for a long time and every time I would go through to thin the herd a bit the trailer would always get me excited and it would survive the thinning. Finally I bought it. Now, my first impression was actually not so great. The tutorial level is pretty brutal and I felt the controls were very slow and clunky at first. I even considered refunding it. Boy am I glad I didn't. I made a few climbs and it did not take long for me to realize just what a great purchase this was. This game is incredible fun and addictive. Just when I think I"m getting a good strategy the game throws a new challenge at me. The diversity of levels and orientations and obstacles is staggering and once you get a grip on how the game controls it no longer feels clunky. It feels very tight and polished. Currently one of my favorite games, and a lot of my other games are getting neglected for Towerclimb and likely will for quite a while. Buy it, even at full price I would highly recommend it.

review:
So, after playing the game for about 20 hours I decided to give this game a short review; "Darksouls in platforming form". Since then, that was my review for a long time. However, I've decided to give this game a more in depth and fair review after almost 50 hours in. 
You will die. There is no exception to this. After every death, you get a death card, and then you start over from the bottom. You have no healthbar; one mistake and your dead. Luckily the game provided revives to help you along the way, but they won't be of any use if you aren't careful. When I first started playing the game, I only thought of it as your typical hard-as-hell rougelike. But every time I died, I went straight back to climbing. You will gradually get better, and the progress is easy to see. Overtime the game has gotten to me. The music is wonderfull, unique, and suprisinly fits each area very well. Along with that, each area has new elements to it that add to the unique challenge each area provides as you climb with the few resources the game provides you. On that note, it is vital that you must utilize everything the game gives you to be succesful. A blast berry you didnt pick up might have you wasting a resource later on, or those golden berries you missed might have become the revive potion you so desperately needed. 
Something so simple as climbing a tower has provided more entertainment and rewarding gameplay then some games do over their lifetime. I can say this game isn't for everyone, but to those who purchase it in hopes for a great platformer, have fun, and never give up

author: {'steamid': '76561197976382770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1482168433}
review:
"5 years in the making" explique le jeu : mouais. Ben il va falloir encore quelques années. Le jeu semble intéressant mais semble se perdre dans sa maniabilité particulière.
La manette xbox n'est pas reconnue par défaut. Après avoir tenté de trouver une façon satisfaisante de répartir les (nombreux) controles du jeu sur ma manette, je suis passé sur clavier.
Ça tombe bien, l'utilisation du clavier est recommandé par les auteurs. Ce qui est moins fun c'est qu'aucune touche n'est mappée et qu'il faut à nouveau tout faire soit même.
Soit.
Je vais donc sur le manuel du jeu et j'apprend que je dois me déplacer avec les flèches du jeu, choisir mes potions avec wasd, sauter avec "X" alors que la barre d'espace sert à se déplacer dans l'inventaire.
Mais euh ?!

Bref, après avoir tenté de me déplacer dans le premier niveau, je comprend vite le souci : Towerclimb semble être plein de bonnes idées, son ambiance musical est intéressante, mais le jeu semble demander au joueur une rigueur constante alors qu'il se permet lui d'être brouillon.

Ce n'est pas seulement la difficulté que j'ai rencontré à mapper mes controles qui m'a frustré mais le niveau de finition du jeu n'est pas satisfaisant : jeu en mode fenetré qui bug selon les résolutions choisies en plein écran, intro du jeu impossible à passer à CHAQUE lancement, impossible de quitter le jeu autrement qu'en faisant un alt+f4, plantages à répétition. Bref, c'est bien trop cher pour ce que c'est actuellement.

review: I must once again commend this game and it's two creators, this game has awed, startled, impassioned, motivated, angered, and left me without words, the words in the human dictionary are not adequate to describe the immaculate of TowerClimb, every side and wall of this game is brimming with love, work, and a passion for the old style of brutal game difficulty, in fact it's the hardest games i've ever played, and amazingly fair for a rouge like, which is good considering it's insane difficulty, after 133 hours i still crave for more runs, the gameplay play is, amazing, thrilling, and most importantly tight, the controls work so well with keybroad and let the be experience absolute pleasure, the music, is just dear fucking lord, Quazi did a fan-fucking-tastic job, this game also wins one of my favorite soundtracks, some of the most catchy, and "hype" sounding content. The art style is what i call foreign and strange and adds to an alien atmosphere, although i do recommend that the pixleblur be turned on, it can be turned off to those less privy to it. And the content is vast, not that it takes lots of time, in fact you could 100% (not including death cards) in a few hours, but the sheer amount of time you must take improving your skill is where the length comes from, and Davio and Quazi did it good job of it and made every death seem fair (besides a few) which is important because your gonna die a lot. to wrap this up, this is one of the few games i could give a unbiased 10/10, the one problem i have with it is that there is no sound option which is bad if you talking on  discord or steam, but besides that there is no other problems besides preference, which brings me into my next point that this game is not for everyone, if you are a semi-casual gamer then consider that this game is incredibly hard, it requires nerves of steel, and skills beyond belief, if you don't have patients don't go right into this game, but please if even after all the talk of harsh difficulty, if you are even a tad bit interested get this game, it's only 15$, and has sadly very few sales at just 7k in about a year, give this game the notice it deserves, the community on discord is awesome and the creators often talk about future projects, so please give this game a chance, i'm overjoyed i found this gem and can now call it my favorite single-player, and rouge-lite of all time. thank you Davio and Quazi, please make more games so i can throw all my $DOSH$ at you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041978087', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 11162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6051, 'last_played': 1666246685}
review:
Towerclimb is a hardcore rogue-like platformer. I do not recommend this game for you if you haven't played something like it before. It is seriously hard, and there is only 1 checkpoint halfway through the main game.

With that said, onto the review.
This game can be compared to Spelunky, where instead of climbing down, you're climbing up. This game is slower paced and less about reflexes, and more about planning the best path to take and using your resources wisely. Despite the levels being randomly generated, situations where you are forced to lose some of your items to get through a level are rare if you are careful with how you use them.

It might take a while to get used to how the game plays, but once you master the controls, it feels satisfying to pull off tricks that you discover as you play. It may not look like it from the store page, but there is quite a lot of stuff in this game. It starts to really get interesting once you get halfway through the game. You will be exited to climb higher and see what lies ahead.

If you loved Spelunky, you will probably love this game as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974989948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 17796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1889, 'last_played': 1569118266}
review:
Voted for “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Steam Award, and the reason I give it this vote is because this game is criminally underappreciated and 'deserves' an award.  Like a few others, I went into this thinking "Cool, it's like Spelunky, but you climb. I'll give it a shot."  I had no idea how wrong I was.

It took some time to get adjusted to the new world of vertical ascention, but every time I'd re-enter the tower, I'd climb a few feet higher than the last, with every step of the way being met with a fresh new challenge, and all new traps to keep my confidence in check. It's a pain, but such trials only fueled my determination to keep making my way towards the top.  It didn't take long before I knew I was hooked.  I had to know what was up there.

My whole climb was filled with thoughts of what mystery awaited me at the top.  An amazing treasure?  A ferocious guardian?  Every foot higher that I climb pushed me harder to keep going, but I was not prepared for what awaited me at the top.

It's uncommon for a game to completely catch me by surprise and leave me stunned, but making it to the top only made me realize that there was much, much more to this tower than meets the eye. And honestly, what I found at the top was exactly what I wanted to see the most.. but it's something you'll have to discover for yourself.

If you're a tough customer who's ready for some true challenge, then get your gear ready because I cannot recommend this game enough. It's gameplay, atmospheric soundtrack, controls, and challenge are all in perfect sync with one another to create a truly unique and solid experience that towers above other roguelikes.  It's tough as nails and unforgiving from the moment you enter the tower, but I wouldn't have it any other way than to earn the rewards waiting at the top.

It's clear how much love and work went into making this adventure, and I can say that this is a true Indie gem that's not only in need of some serious spotlight, but deserves an award for how much this game has to offer.. and I thought it was cool before it got one.

review:
This is one of those games you don't see often. Where not only does it have an amazing soundtrack and visuals, but also some very fun gameplay but being so under the radar it's incredible how a game this good can be so unnoticed.

[h1] + Pros [/h1]

-Music is some of the best I've heard in any game.
-The gameplay is relatively simple yet fun.
-Unique amongst platformers and rogue-likes.
-Plethora of secrets hidden away in the game that will give you hours os searching.
-Fun and difficult hidden challenge mode. [spoiler] Legendary Fragment Run [/spoiler]
-Amazing visuals
-Very fun and unique levels
-Some pretty funny secrets that are guaranteed a laugh.
-Amazing job on atmosphere. (game gets so much better than it already is as you ascend the tower.)
-Fun and intimidating villains
-Hours of gameplay

[h1] ~ Neutral [/h1]

(basically, what can be called good or bad depending on your preference.)

-Hard (there is a difficulty setting for this game that is good for beginners of the game. And it's not Dark Souls or Battle Toads level of hair-pulling, but is definitely a challenge.)
-Lack of story (there is a story, but it is not much of importance for this game and isn't the focus of the game. That goes for characters too. There IS a story that you can piece together but, like I said, it's not really the focus of the game.)

[h1] - Cons [/h1]
-Controls are slightly finicky (sometimes the controls can be unresponsive)

This game is amazing and it still surprises me that it is made by just two people, with one or both I believe still being in college. The devs are very friendly and listen to the fans about what to add. It's also currently on sale for $8 which is a great time to buy for this game when it's worth a lot more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988649454', 'num_games_owned': 645, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 14875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7228, 'last_played': 1609636416}
review:
You are a little climber and your task is to get to the top of the Tower. You do this by running, jumping and climbing walls and ceilings.
It's a simple concept, change the usual right-to-left platforming into an upwards climb. This actually creates many ways of progressing through even relatively simple obstacles. And oh it's executed so well!
You die in one hit and have very limited lives. TowerClimb is hard, but fair. Almost all of the obstacles and enemies are either stationary, or slow and predictable in their movements. Not only that but they also have a set up time and audio/visual cues. You have a fair amount of vision around the climber, giving you a chance to spot enemies from below and think of a way around in advance.
The level layouts are randomly generated, making this game about routing your way up in a way that preserves your resources while not dying. To change things up, there are many different parts of the tower that have enemies and tiles unique to them.
There are also items, like swords, magic wands, springs, hookshots and many more to help you get to the top.

I really like this game; the moment-to-moment gameplay that requires critical thinking and ability to execute difficult maneuvers, fact that almost every death is caused by the player misplaying instead of random bullshit, many things to master.. It's so good.

The amount of buttons (they will take up every button of your controller) and weird way of how the button for running is also used for grabbing and throwing items will take a bit to get used to, but other than that I see no reason to NOT BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW ITS AND EMBARK ON THE JOURNEY TO COLLECT EVERY DEATH CARD AND KICK SOME TRASHBAG WIZARD ASS IT IS PURE JOY TO PLAY.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190375506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2177, 'last_played': 1605232318}
review:
There's a lot to love about TowerClimb.

Every time I play, I feel as if I'm controlling a brave human being with opinons, a family who loves them, an identity, opinions of his or her own, and complete obedience, so when I accidentally jump into a spinning fan blade I feel as if I've foolishly wasted someone's life. Most games just churn out the same protagonist over and over. Despite a simple procedural trick, I feel much more involved with the characters and their elation when we find a pair of climbing gloves, and their fear when they fall from an almost-fatal height.

TowerClimb's visual style is a combination of dynamic lighting and crunchy pixels, and it's beautiful. The character animations are expressive, especially when the avatar pushes against a block or wall. That specific animation almost looks rotoscoped. I can imagine a backstory where the Climbers don their ceremonial one-color climbing suit. The color changes for every climber, so it feels like each avatar has a unique identity.

The controls don't make sense at first, but perservere and they become natural.

The gameplay is tight, hard but mostly fair, though the giant worm miniboss is a bit OP. Even touching its abdomen is fatal, and I think that makes it really to escape it when one is cornered.

There are lots of secrets and side-quests, so the replay value is high, though I haven't beaten the main quest yet I can imagine playing through multiple times to explore the secrets.

The music is great, and very evocative of each level's theme. The music in panic levels, like when the lava rises or the worm chases you, is pretty good at getting novice players to crack under stress and die, which is always entertaining. It takes some concentration to tune it out, but it's doable.

There's substantial support and hints on the wiki, so novice players such as myself can pick up a lot of the knowledge required for a successful run, but don't be fooled, this game is very skill-based. The game includes a playthrough log, so I can clearly see that I'm getting progressively better.

I'm glad it's not item-based, and I'm glad that nothing carries over from my previous runs. The game is very well balanced, and you will become a better Climber with experience. Good luck!

I really enjoy TowerClimb, and I think I'll play it for a long time.
