author: {'steamid': '76561197996334383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 9423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8302, 'last_played': 1664148287}
review:
[b]Summary[/b]

TowerClimb is a game in which, oddly enough, you climb a tower.  It is very difficult, and every death comes as a learning experience. There are tonnes of nuances and tricks that you learn as you play to improve your speed and efficiency, and figuring new ones out is always satisfying.  Compared to other games in this genre, Towerclimb plays much slower, and many players actually dislike that weapons aren't something you get to use very frequently. There also isn't any form of unlock system found in other roguelite games where even if you die you're still making progress.  Despite this, TowerClimb is perfect for those who don't mind starting from square one at every death, and love learning from their mistakes.  
===========================
[b]Pros:[/b]
===========================
-Extremely difficult (for those who enjoy that sort of thing)
-Very few deaths feel "unfair", and even the ones that are unfair are still a learning experience
-Excelent sound track
-Photos of all of your deaths get listed on a handy-dandy chart so you can view your progress and possibly see where your mistakes have been made 
-The wiki isn't very expansive. This is a good thing, as finding things out on your own is just so much better.
===========================
[b]Cons:[/b]
===========================
-Extremely difficult (for those who don't enjoy that sort of thing)
-Some runs can take upwards of an hour , so if you don't have much time to spend on this game you might not like it
-The main mode as a "side quest" that is heavily dependant on RNG being in your favor

-------------------------------------

[b]TL;DR:[/b] It's a wonderful game. Very tough, but with many different nuances and tricks, you can learn to master the tower. After all, every death is a learning experience.



Nominated for the award "I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award".  A relatively unknown title, and that makes me really sad.

The year after that, I nominated this game for the "Unconditional Love" steam award, or whatever it was called.

review:
Ce jeu est un pur chef d'oeuvre, un bijou injustement méconnu, passé inaperçu par hasard ou du fait de sa forme rebutante. Il s'agit d'un des meilleurs représentants que je connaisse du genre "roguelike", assez similaire à Spelunky dans l'esprit.

Le monde (la tour) est rempli d'éléments tous plus étonnants les uns que les autres, qui vous terroriseront la première fois que vous les rencontrerez, surtout si vous etes en train de battre votre record de hauteur. Tout, ou presque (y compris certains bonus) peut vous tuer, et pourtant, rien de véritablement injuste. Avec un peu de prudence, il peut vous arriver de comprendre et de surmonter un obstacle qui vous était complètement inconnu auparavant.

Les contrôles sont difficiles à appréhender au départ, mais une fois maitrisés, vous vous rendrez compte de leur richesse : ce qu'ils permettent, en termes de gestion de situations, est prodigieux. Vous finirez par savoir ce que vous pouvez faire ou non, et à quelles conditions. Vous vous surprendrez à passez aisément des lieux qui vous avaient semblés impossibles, tout simplement parce que vous aurez compris le fonctionnement des divers éléments. Ce qui est particulièrement agréable est que la génération procédurale nous confronte à des situations toujours nouvelles, mais composées d'éléments dont on apprend vite à prévoir le comportement (pâles de ventilateur, lasers, blocs qui tombent, pics, et même animaux, obéissent tous à des schémas très simples).

Un mot sur la direction artistique : il s'agit d'un pixel-art assez sommaire, dans une résolution trop basse pour nos écrans, forçant presque à jouer en mode fenetré. Et pourtant, le filtre appliqué à ces pixels, qui donne un aspect impressioniste, contribue, avec la bande son magnifique, à former une véritable ambiance. 
Or, cette création d'une ambiance, quand on l'ajoute à celle de situations inédites par le gameplay et les éléments du monde du jeu, fait selon moi de ce jeu un véritable chef d'oeuvre.
On voit que la personne (je crois qu'elle était plus ou moins seule) qui a fait ce jeu l'a travaillé, avec passion, jusque dans ses moindres détails. Elle y a même mis un humour surprenant et discret, qui insuffle au titre une personnalité forte (je n'en dirai pas plus pour ne pas gâcher les surprises).

Enfin, car c'est important : le contenu est suffisamment important pour vous donner envie de jouer pendant longtemps. Je ne sais pas exactement l'étendue de ce que propose le jeu, car je ne l'ai pas fini, mais ce que j'en ai vu justifie déjà, à mon sens, l'achat du jeu au prix "fort".


En résumé : roguelike exigeant avec direction artistique incroyable. Essayez-le, et surtout ne vous arrêtez pas à la première impression, due avant tout à la rigidité apparente des contrôles et à la faible résolution. Chef d'oeuvre !

review:
Towerclimb is an incredibly well designed roguelike, it's challenging, and all the mechanics in the game really work together to create a lot of depth. The game is also quite fair, and very rarely puts you in no-win situations, if you know what you're doing.

That said, the game has a lot of mechanics that need to be learned early on, so it may seem frustrating to new players, my suggestion is to stick with it, and possibly read a few guides. This is the kind of game where players with 100s of hours in the game still die frequently at the game's harder levels, so don't feel bad if you die a bit early on. Spend enough hours in the game, and you'll be breezing through the early levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072092667', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 9763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3680, 'last_played': 1698667402}
review:
For a brief summary of the game:
You are a tiny man. You must climb the tower. The tower and its denizens will kill you. Lots.

This game is incredibly fun, and infinitely replayable. Levels are randomly generated with each character, and death is permanent (save for limited revive potions you can obtain). The challenge is always new, and always tests your skill. 

There is so much love and attention to detail packed into the game. The core mechanics and progression are solid, and optional, hidden areas provide plenty of additonal challenge. The community is open and friendly (the devs and players *will* stop by if you stream)

In all, this game is fun. With yourself, with friends in co-op, with Zardo chasing after you. If you like platformers and want a challenge, this is the game. (plus, with talks of a level-creator to be released eventually, there's no worry of you ever running out of things to do)

author: {'steamid': '76561198060441782', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 10490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1492, 'last_played': 1677439621}
review:
I won't bother writing a long, detailed review as to why this game is so great, seeing as others have already done so. 

What I will do is say this; Every other roguelike game I've played has felt like just that - a game. I fire up the game and play it with an emotional investment similar to that of a game of chess or Minesweeper. They just feel like games, no more and no less.

But this game is different. It doesn't feel like a game. It feels like an ADVENTURE. The music, the atmosphere, the imaginative level, monster, and character designs all make this world feel like more than just another rearrangement of the same levels. It's a roguelike, but every time I play it feels like something more than "just another run." Maybe this sounds too corny, but Towerclimb brought to the table something I've wanted in roguelikes for quite some time. I honestly didn't think these kinds of games could get this good. 

In sum: If you like roguelikes, platforming, and want a game that really tries to be more than just a game, then you should totally give this game a try.

review:
If you enjoy a serious challenge, TowerClimb offers a great amount of content. The tower features a wide variety of interesting environments and secrets, and getting to the end is very rewarding. One major gripe I have is that the controls are really bad.

Even after you manage to complete a normal run, there are many more challenges to take on and secrets to discover. These extras are some of the most brutally difficult feats in roguelite history. You can easily spend hundreds of hours attempting these, so if you're a hardcore maniac, you can get a lot out of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050440065', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1491, 'last_played': 1607048313}
review:
Duas palavras : Unicamente fantástico !  Esse jogo é uma raridade. Muito provavelmente você não verá um semelhante tão cedo. A trilha sonora é excelente e totalmente coerente com os níveis, que por sua vez são sempre diferentes e contam com um motor de criação muito bom posto que nunca bugam ou se tornam impossíveis, embora sempre as fases sejam diferentes e únicas. E o número de níveis que há para subir... eu simplesmente ainda não consegui zerar, ver todos os andares, porque o jogo tem uma dificuldade bem alta. Creio que uma das melhores sensações que há nele é que em determinado momento você se sente na pele do personagem e realmente quer muito subir até o topo, e uma das coisas que contribui com isso é o fato de sempre que começamos uma nova fase há um novo personagem com um novo nome e uma nova roupa. É outro tentando realizar seu sonho de chegar ao topo !
No entanto, devo dizer que o achei o preço meio alto, embora o jogo seja bom e valha o seu tempo. Recomendo esperar uma promoção de pelo menos uns 40 % de desconto pra ficar em um preço justo.
Pode começar a subir, e não se esqueça, a coragem dele nunca deve ser esquecida :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198067551697', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 21475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6, 'playtime_at_review': 15185, 'last_played': 1711992279}
review:
I gladly recommend this game because of many things.

First of all, for a roguelike, it has absolutely no mercy. Imagine if Spelunky and I Wanna Be The Guy meet, and you get an idea of how difficult it is.

On top of that, the game is long, and the challenge keeps growing as the levels go on.
So, basically, what you need to play this game is patience, humility, and sheer determination if you want to reach the end... so it's not a good fit for everyone.

Besides your additionnal "HP", you can also count your ressources (potions, items) as another HP bar too, because if you run out of them, the terrain generation may likely stop you.

I've done it all, every gamemode requires a different approach and different skills, the most common in all of them is endurance. Beating it has never been more worth it from any other game I've played. Even with no steam achievements, I deeply feel every bit of success this game offered. This game left me a print that won't never go away.

Pros :
- The atmosphere. The musics are fitting very well to the slow pace of the game.
- The original way to manage items. It's part of the steep learning curve.
- The feeling of accomplishement once you complete something (quest, zones, mini games)
- No time limit. You can take all the time you want to strategize your actions and manage your items. (except when there is lava, but that's close to non-existent in later stages)
- A perfect run require to fill your inventory with key items, which makes the game all the more challenging for those who could find this game somewhat easy.
- Multiplayer. Reviving your teammates is cheaper than reviving yourself. Inventory is shared among players so there's no way to cheese the legend fragment run ;)

Anti-Pros :
- 1 checkpoint, practicing the later stages can be very brutal.
- No steam achievement (yet ?)
- The coliseum of 50 waves, oh dear.
- No pausing, even when the windows is out of focus. At least you can wait at places where you're safe.

And remember, chapter 3 is coming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023639387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 9330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7730, 'last_played': 1663896769}
review:
This is a roguelite platformer that is criminally under played.

TowerClimb provides a very unique blend of atmosphere and challenge.
There are a plethora of opportunities to utilize the environment to your advantage: Need something to kill those monsters? Blow up those spikes and use them as improvised throwing weapons. Want equipment to climb even faster? Cook the rat meat in lava and give them to the crafter when you see him next etc.
Dangers you will face include terrain eating giant worms, rising lava, malevolent mages and spinning lazers; which you can often twist to your advantage to.

The soundtrack is amazing, and reaches a whole new level in the second chapter. The same can be said about the evolution of the graphics. The dev team have been extremely active in addressing player feedback across the last 5 years of the games development.

[h1]Not for everyone?[/h1]
Be advised that it is also one of the most brutal platformers out there. Most players won’t see beyond the first 1/3rd of the content the game has to offer within the first 50 hours.
You can only carry one (replenishable) revive potion at a time (two on "easy" mode) and there are a few hazards like lava that will destroy you instantly regardless. BS deaths are extremely rare (<5% of deaths) but there are a few things early on that could be telegraphed better (like giant bats suddenly zipping across the screen). There is only one checkpoint for chapter 2 after the 20th floor. The game is very fair, however, and with the right combination of practice, brains and reflexes you will prevail...

Controls are a bit different, but become very intuitive after with an hour of practice or less (not sure why so many of those posting negative reviews played only a few minutes and forgot that they are fully rebindable).
My main nit-pick is that there is currently no proper way to pause the game if you're interrupted (though you can use <alt> in windowed mode, but this won't allow you to swap to other applications mid play). Thankfully though it usually only takes a few minutes to get to reach the safety of the transition screen.

[h1]Game Content/Length[/h1]
In terms of content the game is huge: There are 14 main areas, each having some of their own unique mechanics across 46 levels. Such include bug sanctuaries, factories of death, disco club of twisted apparitions etc. There are some deadly secret areas to such as the world within the arcade machine as well as bonus unlockable game modes like Z-Ball.
The levels themselves are randomized each time you play so you’re forced to learn generalist strategies rather than rote learn layouts.
I've played a lot of roguelite platformers (also involved in making one called "Aura of Worlds"), and I found that TowerClimb has provided over 100 hours of engagement post main campaign. I still need to complete the bonus challenges such as the Colossus arena and 7 legendary fragment run...


[h1]TLDR:[/h1]
Want a game with a focus on explorative wonder and strategic challenge? Buy this :)!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999291428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2070, 'last_played': 1526426374}
review:
*DISCLAIMER: Purchased at -40% price during Summer Sale*

I know a whole bunch of people will likely be getting this game due to it being on the sales. So, let me just say up front. This is a game that requires a lot from you. And well...I came close to not reaching those requirements. See, the controls are very unusual - They take a LOT of getting used to and they are VERY frustrating to use at first. So frustrating that, for the past half hour of play, I had been seriously considering getting a refund on this - But not due to any real fault of the developer. Any other time, I would have been okay to just eat the paltry £6 cost and put it on my "to come back to" pile. But I am currently between jobs, so I do not have the luxury to do that. If I got a game, I told myself, it had to be something I would be happy investing in, so at first, I was close to refunding it. 

But then I got better at the game. 

Oh man. This is the sort of game you got back in the day where you intially find it terrible, but because you were a kid and refunds weren't a viable option, you'd keep muscling through, trying to like it...Until eventually you have that breakthrough and end up adoring it. 

Something clicked with me on my tenth run, and I got all the way up to floor 8. It was exhilirating. 

I would give this a tentative reccomendation, just...Know what you're getting in for. But if you're the sort of gamer that can deal with wonky controls if it results in a wonderful experience once you're used to it...Go for it. I've made far worse investments on Steam.

EDIT: 24 hours of played time later, and I have to say that the game only gets better as time goes on. Everyone thinks I'm an utter lunatic, but I love this game now. I love it so, so much. I will not spoil anything, but...After the halfway point (You'll know when it is), the game just takes a massive, unpredictable turn and goes absoloutly off the wall. Saying any more would spoil the "WHOAAAAA" aspect of it that I had, but...It is almost Undertale levels of out-of-nowhere depth and change. 

And something I forgot to mention before? The music. OH. MY. GOD. Why is it that obscure games tend to have truly incredible soundtracks? This is a prime example, and more people need to hear it. So underrated, but so amazing. 

Forget that tentative reccomendation - It now has a wholehearted reccomendation from me. But I'll say again. Bring your best. Show no mercy to the Tower, as you will receive none.

review:
It makes me sad that really amazing games like this slip through the cracks completely.  I've been following the development of this game for years, and it would be a well-known classic if it didn't disappear deep into Steam's bowels within moments of its release.  It's not anyone's fault, there's certainly a huge market for indie games.. but without hype, a game has no chance at all.

This game is great.  Pure skill-based climbing and platforming, very deep and will take weeks to master (if not longer).  Very nice art style as well, and looks great in motion.  The controls take some getting used to, but it's worth it.

review:
[h1]Read this first[/h1]

I will start this review by pointing out some core features which can hold you back from enjoying/buying the game.
[list]
[*]The game is very difficult, has a steep learning curve and involves a lot of skill
[*]The game contains only one checkpoint. It will take probably 30 min to reach the checkpoint and 1.5 hours to beat the game starting from this checkpoint. Total game length is approximately 2 hours.
[*]No Save & Exit feature
[*]It has permadeath
[*]Pixel Graphics
[*]This is not a rogue-like game but has rogue-like elements, you should buy this game mainly because you like platformers. I Don't recommend buying it if you are looking for a rogue-like game.
[*]Controls: Scroll down to the Controls & Physics section for the reason why.
[/list]

[h1]Game description and my experience[/h1]

In this platformer your goal is to reach the top of the tower. This will be mainly achieved by climbing the side of blocks and wall of the tower. There are 46 floors (excluding many secret floors). The theme of the floors change every 3 floors, like 3 snow covered floors after 3 lava maps etc. The floors are littered with blocks, enemies, items, chests, obstacles and sometimes a witch which will sell you potions and lifes or a crafter which will craft items if you hand over multiple items and a small fee for crafting (check out the wiki for item combinations). Resources help you overcome the tower and on some floors it is a requisite. So gathering resources is an important element in the game. Items can change your character's properties like raising run and climbing speed.

On normal difficulty you will carry one extra life which can be refilled at the witch for a few golden berries, which are spread throughout the floors. The layout of the floors is randomized thanks to procedural generation and keeps the replayability high, creating unique situations and is the major reason why I think this the most replayable platformer I have encountered. This also makes sure the game involves a lot of skill and takes away being good at the game by memorizing the level unlike many other platformers. You will die a lot in this game not because the game is unfair but more like the slightest misstep often result in death.You need to train yourself to become better and reach higher floors. Persistency is key here. It took me 15 hours to reach the checkpoint and finished the game exactly at the 100 hour mark for a game with a length of 2 hours while I'm familiar with difficult platformers.

This game is about improving your runs which will probably happen with baby steps. The game can play with your mental state for example, when you are closing in at the end and aware that every small misstep means that you throw away all your progress can make an ordinary jump look like an extreme hurdle, it suddenly becomes a scary thing. The process up until the moment you die is fun but never frustrating and can be tense. The reason is because this game is fair, there are no cheap shots. If you die it always is due to your own fault. Once you get the hang of the controls and being familiar at what the tower is throwing at you the experience changes from a slight tense to a relaxing one where mastering the game feels almost zen-like. 

Reaching higher floors feel rewarding especially clearing the game similar as what Dark Souls does. Level design is not only diverse for its graphical appearance but also for its playstyle. Some floors require fast or slow climbing, avoiding certain enemies, let you use more resources or force you to use certain objects. You are not simply playing the game but rather experience it. Conquering the tower feels like completing an epic journey. 

[h1]Controls & Physics[/h1]

The first thing you will notice when starting out is the, what you will think of, weird control layout. There are multiple functions assigned to a button. For example jump and attack shares the same button, so you cannot attack without jumping. This is done because there will be moments where you have to do a combination of different actions within a short timeframe like jumping, catching an item, store this item, dodging an enemy, Scroll through your inventory to take a different weapon and attack the same enemy. It doesn't work if you are playing twister on your controller when using one button for every action. The control scheme does make sense, although this doesn't seem obvious when you first start out, keep this in mind. This point is repeatedly brought forward in negative reviews, people don't seem to understand.

The most common things I don't like in general with platform games are lag between controls and the actual movement of the character, the feel if as characters are walking on ice especially when turning around or floaty physics. There are no such things in towerclimb, the controls are responsive, tight and the physics are spot on. You may struggle with the controls due to the layout and it takes a while before getting used to as described above. Another important factor to me is the flow of the gameplay, which is fine in this game, you are always on the move.

[u]Small sidenote[/u]: Using the left trigger while holding the right one and vice versa on a xbox 360 controller doesn't work. Using them simultaneous is impossible. You can solve it by using the cheap software called Controller Companion on steam. Even if you don't buy this game I highly recommend that piece of software.

[h1]Graphics, Sound & Music[/h1]

The graphics of this game are minimalistic. You can argue that it is a step back from modern gaming but in the end it comes down whether you like the pixel style. I like the pixel style and also see it more as an art style. Despite the minimalistic approach there is a lot attention to detail. When it comes down to sounds there is great diversity although simple. Every item has its own sound when executing an attack, throwing or picking it up. Enemies have different sounds for movement, patrolling, attacking, being attacked etc. A strong point of this game is its great soundtrack. The musics fits the game very well, from ambient eerie sounds, mysterious tunes to dance music. It has characteristic tracks with great diversity. It really helps setting the mood on a floor.

[h1]Final Word[/h1]

I played a lot of platform games in my life from old school titles like the Mario, Crash Bandicoot and Donkey Kong Country series to modern platformers like N+ and Super Meat Boy, but I have to say this is the best platformer I have played. DKC2 was my favorite one for almost 20 years up till the moment I played towerclimb. It is also the most difficult, replayable and addictive one, a true classic in my book and ridiculously overlooked. A prime example of an indie gem lost in a sea of titles on steam. Or like a reviewer mentioned ''It's probably the best kept secret on steam right now actually''. Worth every penny. One thing that can make this game even better is a level editor, including level sharing via steam workshop. Top of the food chain material.

review:
I've played towerclimb since it was in beta, and when I learned that they had finally relesaed the game and it was avalible on steam I was very excited; and my excitement was worth it.

Towerclimb is a difficult game. It has permadeath, and little forgiveness for mistakes. The gameplay consists of you trying to climb as the inside of this tower as high as you can, in hopes to reach the top. You achieve this mainly through platforming. There are climbing mechanics, your character can climb on walls and ceilings to get to where they need to go.

There are a ton of items you can use to survive and climb higher. These items add a very light RPG element to the game and different players will have different preferred methods for survivng the terrible tower. 

The art design look great. It has a very dark and foggy atmposhphere. The music is also very good- dark and foggy but also triumphant and powerful.

If you like games where you are continually improving a run, games where death comes from not properly preparing or utalizing your tools, then this game is for you.

review:
TLDR: Frustrating Controls 

Im in the tutorial and im so frustrated by the controls, it just makes no sense.

I am supposed to pick up an item from the ground by standing still on an item but holding the sprint button (which is just contradictory), and press C to add it to my inventory for some reason, while my inventory opens with W. In the inventory you have to press CTRL to switch items per example. The tutorial then asks to place a crate, but items are automatically thrown away when you release the button, so you have to hold the button or the item will be thrown. To place the crate on the ground, you have to throw it upwards, which is a strange solution but alright. Then I get a weapon and I am supposed to attack with it by sprinting and jumping at the same time (???) It just all feels so wrong, the hotkeys chosen, the way they need to be executed, so much feels wrong, im sorry. I rather watch someone play it than play it myself. 

Also why does the 30seconds intro play every time ?
Edit: You can close the intro with pressing "X"

@Devs, you really need to rework this control system, its a total mess and breaks all conventions of what people know about controlling a platformer. Its strange, complicated, unintuitive and makes me want to stop the game before ending the tutorial. Keys are somewhat rebindable but these are mostly that can not be fixed by changing keys.

Towerclimb does simple things wrong that Mario did right 20 years ago. 

Let me know when/if it is reworked and im changing the review no problem, but I currently can't have fun with it.
developer_response:
There's so much misinformation in this review.

You've only played 30 minutes, barely enough time to even scratch the surface of this game or it's controls, or why they were made this way.

You claim that you can't jump off the wall "like in super meat boy". If you played this game longer than 30 minutes you'd have easily figured out this can be done with jump potions/aura. Comparing this game's controls to simple twitch platformers like meat boy is like asking why a roguelike isn't as simple as pacman. It's simply an invalid comparison. There's much more that can be done in this game. Here's a quote from someone with 500+ hours playtime: 

"People have complained that the controls are very inconvenient and don't make very much sense. Trust me, they do, and you'll get the hang of it with some practice." 

Play, and you'll see that the controls make sense once you understand the game and it's nuances. There's a lot of subtle things you can do. This game is very strategic, complex, and vast. Do not expect to be good at the game in 30 minutes.

You claim throwing the crate upwards is the only way to place it on the ground. You can simply hold down and drop it. Since the tutorial didn't tell you this word for word, you thought you could only place it by throwing it straight up.

You claim the intro plays every time. You can skip it by pressing jump.

You claim switching items with CTRL isn't explained, when it VERY CLEARLY is.

You simply got frustrated at a game you didn't play, and a control scheme you didn't immediately understand, and left a negative review full of misformation, based on controls you don't understand. There's a reason many people say this game is among their all time favorites; just read any reviews with actual playtime.

If you get frustrated by learning a unique control scheme then this game might be too much for you. Complete the game, then come back and say the controls don't make sense. You won't if you get that far.

review:
There may be a good game in there but a lack of polish means you'll have to dig to find out.

Some standard conventions are ignored, which results in unwarranted frustration (especially considering how easy it is to include them).  The game doesn't start in full screen.  At certain points ESC will exit the game rather than the context you're in (like a menu).  Worst of all, the control scheme is arcane and confused despite decades of great examples to draw on.  

The market for games is incredibly saturated at this point and you can find free flash games that do everything right, so I find it difficult to recommend a game (even an interesting one) when it lamely leaves barriers to entry that, for $10 - $15, could easily and should have been eliminated.

review:
I didn't hear about TowerClimb until recently. I wasn't sure if I was going to like it at first. Seem very brutal with only 1 extra life (2 with easy mode). However as I watched others play it I knew I had to get this game.

It's intense.

Once you know how the control works it becomes an incredible journey. You are a man/woman. You want to climb the tower. You are weak but you are resourceful. You never felt so impowered and powerless at the same time. You feel the clinging to the rock as if your life depends on it. There is jumps that you will question because you won't be sure if the distance is close enough to make it. You will be put in situations that may force you to use an item because it's the differnce between life and death. Often death will come A lot. The controls are tight, the music fits perfectly, and I like the art (pixelated, not the weird filter seen in the trailer).

It's a good game. Strongly recommend it if you enjoy Spelunky or other roguelike/lite games.

Last, there is a log of all the deaths you encounter with a kill screenshot for each one. It's really cool to see your progress on an interactive graph. If you ever feel discouraged playing this game, take a look at the graph and you can see yourself get better as you play. I still die on lower floors but it makes me want to climb higher.

EDIT: After completing the first section of the game I was pleasantly surprised at the additional content that is available. This game, in theory, has a ton of replay value. There is a challenging game mode aside from the main story that takes everything you learn from the main game and mismatches it all. The result is a 'hard mode' that will really push your skills beyond the limits. Don't be decived, this game really has a ton of content

review:
Apesar de eu não ter jogado quase nada, eu assisto quase todas as vezes que um dos meus amigos na lista do Steam joga e ele tem mais de 50h de gameplay, então, apesar de eu não jogar, pode-se dizer que eu tenho em torno de 50h de gameplay de experiencia teorica do jogo.

Este jogo é muito bom, Tower Climb é um jogo de Aventura, Rogue-Like e Procedural, isso significa que cada vez que você jogar, será uma partida diferente. O jogo é bem desafiador, mas como a maioria dos jogos, se você pegar a manha de como lidar com os inimigos você facilmente consegue evita-los.

No Tower Climb o melhor que você pode fazer para lidar com os inimigos é evita-los, matar apenas em casos extremos aonde sua vida dependa da morte do inimigo, pois você não tem muito recurso para gastar tentando mata-los.

O grafico do jogo é muito bonito e os auidos são bem legais, as musicas são viciantes.

Apenas um erro com este jogo, os comandos são uma bosta.
Não me pergunte o porque mas os Devs deste jogo acharam que seria melhor por o botão de "Attack" e "Jump" no mesmo comando, forçando os jogadores  a pularem 100% das vezes que for atacar os inimigos, algo completamente sem logica, na minha opinião. Se os Devs fossem mais inteligentes eles veriam que isso é imbecil e adicionariam um comando novo para separar o botão de "Jump" e de "Attack".

Tirando este pequeno problema que interfere gravemente no Gameplay, o jogo é otimo.

Pelo fato deste pequeno erro, eu não aconcelho ninguem a comprar o jogo por fullprice, mas seria mais adequado a compra-lo em alguma promoção.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970287177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 1675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1642, 'last_played': 1697742840}
review:
20 Minutes With Towerclimb:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vVy7oY8-f-U

[H1]The Good[/H1] Fantastic, suspenseful rogue-lite experience full of thrills and endless content. Earthy, low-resolution pixel art combined with pretty lighting effects oozes atmosphere. Tight, responsive controls. Lots of level variety, fully destructable environments. Sometimes it makes you think slow and carefully, working your way through environmental puzzles while trying to conserve resources. Other times it will push you to your limit, forcing you to work your way up the tower as fast as humanly possible. 6-player local cooperative (fantastic). Supports split-screen or same-screen, but I have yet to test that feature.

[H1]The Bad[/H1] Technically primitive. Screen stretching not implemented well, so playing without a black border seems like a no-go (for now). Head-scratching interface choices (Shift-Esc to exit to main menu?), and analog controls that desperately need a dead-zone adjustment. One slip could kill you, you don't want it to be the fault of your controller. The control scheme itself could benefit from few more buttons, as you often find yourself playing twister with your fingers to pull items out, keep them in hand, and use them with care.

[H1]The End[/H1] Highly recommended for fans of the Rogue-lite genre, specifically fans of Spelunky. This is Spelunky in reverse, but more cerebral, and more suspenseful. What could be more terrifying than dangling over a great abyss, hanging from your fingertips, wondering if your next move could be your last?

review:
スペランキーなどに似たローグライクアクション。
ただあちらは『降りる』のに対して、こちらは『登る』ので、色々と勝手が違う。
崖から手を放して落ちてしまうという漫画みたいな出来事がしょっちゅう起こる。
ＰＶでは元気に動き回っているが、独特な操作感に慣れるのに時間がかかり、チュートリアルさえも結構難しかったりする。

登った高さが記録されたり、プレイ前に英語の格言が出てきたりと、山登りの辛さがテーマなのか、やけに難易度が高い。
残念なのは、後のステージの方がギミックが多彩で楽しいのに、そこに行くまでが辛いという事。
いくらローグライクでも最初のステージを何度もやる辛さは同じ。

ショートカットがたまにあったり、突発イベントがあったり、プレイヤーを飽きさせない工夫が微笑ましい。
ただ、コインを取るミニゲームがあるのだが、クリアできずに時間切れになったら、さっさと溶岩に落ちて〇ね的な事を言われた。
他にも初見殺しな仕掛けがいくつかある辺り、開発者はドＳだと思われる。

山登りのように忍耐の必要なアクションを望んでいるならおすすめ。目指せ塔頂！おれはもうだめだ。

review:
In many ways, I find this is a game you have to experience. Not because of a heavy reliance on story or art, but because the mechanics of the game and every new thing introduced are just that interesting. Each area you see will kill you in new and interesting ways, and there is just something novel about being utterly destroyed time and time again knowing that you could have done better. This game accomplishes that. Thoroughly. Like, seriously, did you have to make it so that the ledge cling mechanic locks you there specifically when it is inconvenient?
Playing towerclimb is like being in a relationship, you'll be up countless nights playing with it. You'll spend countless hours at your job thinking, "I KNOW I can get to the third [strike]base[/strike] area", and you'll spend countless more hours wondering how to do so. You love it yet you want to strangle it. In a romantic kind of way.

Just remember: BUY A CONTROLLER. I love the game, I really do, but the controls on keyboard are unsavory. Its probably better for your hands in the long run as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2304, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1543619650}
review:
There's a certain look and feel that Super Nintendo games had that gets me like no other games do. It's hard to put my finger on exactly, but I think it was a combination of soft-edged sprites and synth woodwind soundtrack that gave a lot of titles a deep, otherworldly feel. TowerClimb somehow manages to evoke that same sense of depth and wonder while relentlessly murdering me again and again in the most delightful ways.

Part of the unique feel of TowerClimb comes from the mysterious, parable-like setup for the game. There are immense stone towers, people keep trying to climb them, and no one knows what's at the top. You control a never-ending series of unfortunates who challenge the tower, mantling up through floor after deadly floor. It plays a lot like a reverse Spelunky, with your character able to run, jump, scale walls, and crawl along ceilings in search of the exit high above. In place of treasure are tools like crates and springs, and golden berries that can be traded for potions that let you double-jump, break blocks, and teleport.

You're going to need every move and tool at your disposal, though, because the levels in TowerClimb are bizarre and merciless. Sometimes you'll enter a level and it'll start filling with lava. Sometimes everything will be coated in acid. Sometimes carnivorous worms burst from the walls. And sometimes there are pleasant, floaty dandelion-things to ride... straight into the jaws of a bloodthirsty hound. Even if the level gimmick isn't out for your hide, the random generation might very well give you an improbable network of tricky jumps to the exit, far worse than anything you may have encountered in the likes of Spelunky. I'm not kidding about the challenge here, and if not for all the neat things to find and entertaining ways to die, it might not be worth overcoming.

But there is indeed a lot to discover in the tower, and the pixellated graphics make experimentation essential to figuring out what you're encountering. Enemies may get the best of you the first time you meet them, in part because they can be very unpredictable but mainly because you might not know what they are at first. You'll run into all manner of plants and animals, NPCs, chests, shortcuts, and more among the randomly-generated floors. Navigating is always challenging given some of the layouts, but your control over your character is very precise and allows for masterful moves once you fully grok the mantling.

It's hard and you're going to die a ton, but TowerClimb makes it look so good you'll hardly mind. The graphics remind me very much of the old SNES Lemmings port, with chunky detail and silky-smooth animations and bizarre, impossible terrains. Sound design is also excellent, with some very detailed effects and a soundtrack reminiscent of ancient titles like Soul Blazer and Super Metroid in parts. The unexpected nostalgia rush definitely colors my view but make no mistake, TowerClimb is a tight, challenging roguelike platformer with plenty of wonders to offer.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

review:
I've played many more hours than Steam says, having bought it in beta.

It's one of my favourite platformers ever. Together with spelunky, this was a procedurally generated platformer with roguelike elements before it was cool (it's been in development for that long).

Don't expect Spelunky though. Towerclimb is slower, grittier and even more difficult. You have to be even more careful and it's more about evasion than killing stuff. It's fun cause it's difficult and you die a lot. There are several general level themes in the first part of the game (standard caves, jungle, lava caverns...) and special levels (rising lava, water levels, levels where you fly on giant flying plant ballons and more/weirder). And once you finish that, which will take closer to tens of hours, there's chapter two that has more specific (some could say gimmicky, imo a good thing in a game like this) and even more difficult levels, where the gameplay is a bit different.

The graphics was pixel art before it was cool. It's pretty nice and features some cool shader effects, but I understand people who have enough of that. Also the music is excellent.

Towerclimb has local coop and it is even more fun (and a bit easier, since, unlike spelunky, it's not that easy to harm each other. The biggest problem is that setting up controllers is a pain in the ass.

This definitely belongs among the best roguelite platformers and I recommend it to everyone who enjoys the genre. If current price seems like too much, at least put it in your wishlist until it goes lower, cause it's worth it.

review:
This game has clicked with me. Hard. I love procedurally generated games, especially platformers, and this game offers a challenge unlike most others. It's never unfair, as all of my deaths were my own fault, so it avoids being too frustrating or annoying. What it IS, is satisfying. REALLY satisfying. Getting past just the first room/area was a challenge, and it felt GREAT getting past it. 

That's not even the first level, just the first ROOM in the first level, and they're always different. One level had rising lava for no real reason, one other had dogs on every ledge, one was full of wasps, and yet I always had a great time. The graphics are both retro and modern (thanks to amazing lighting effects) and charming as hell, and the music is great. I love roguelikes and I play a lot of them, but I think this is one that will stick with me for a very, very long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002544026', 'num_games_owned': 1424, 'num_reviews': 189, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1455895059}
review:
This game is a real gem hidden amongst the crowd and im glad i've found it.

The premise of the game is simple: Your character, through some sort of sheer bravery, lust for death or perhaps morbid curiosity, decides to enter a tower full of monsters, traps and random layouts to climb to the top (Cause why the hell not?).

There's really nothing else to the game. Im serious! That's [i]literally[/i] all this game is about! The experience whilst climbing the tower however is unbelievably satisfying and I have to admit i never though i'd see myself replaying this game again.

The game is kept extremely simple. Simple controls, simple UI (I think all there is is that menu on the left that displays your current inventory, items etc) simple shop/npc system (All ive seen so far is some guy asking for stuff and a witch selling you potions/items) and simple goal (Get to the top). In fact, there really is no reason to look at a wiki or guide for this game since everything is so simple to figure out (Or that could just be me).

I think one thing the game does very well is making everything your own doing. I dont know how to put it. If you fall to your death/get mauled by a dog/burn in lava/ dismembered by a trap/ punctured by spikes and all sorts of other things, its [i]entirely your fault[/i]. In retrospect, it is a really does feel like an achievement when you actually do make it out past a level without dying. Very little is left to chances and alot of it is to do with skill. That's something i found enjoyable.

In terms of content however, im not exactly sure. Im not one to look into wikis and guides cause in my extreme minority opinion, looking at a guide or wiki destroys a very large part of playing the game (Figuring out stuff!). With that said, ive only seen very few items variety, 2 special level events (Lava and a worm thing), about 4 to 5 different map biome/layout/type, 2 NPCs and 1 special door (Path of exiles shortcut). I dont know if this was planned to make the game remain as simple as possible or not but it's very likely that im still missing out on a ton of content such as secrets and future levels (I believe I've only made it up until 2.5k feet).

I guess the best way to make a comparison for this game is to say it's upward spelunky with less content and [strike]more tears[/strike] more skill. Either ways, im pretty sure this game is worth the 30RM/10$ i paid for it. At least im pretty darn sure it's better spent on them then [i]SOME[/i] other games...

author: {'steamid': '76561198039815575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1590184823}
review:
I've been following this game for about three years, starting with the Let's Play series done by JSmithOTI, a youtuber who covers many different games. The idea of the game and its unique art style immediately caught my attention. I had been familiar with rogue-likes and different platformers; the original Spelunky is one of my favorite games and I saw a lot of similar aspects in TowerClimb. 

I finally made the jump to purchase the game in April of 2015 while the game was still in beta and began playing it religiously. I got a good deal of my own friends into it and they themselves enjoyed the challenge posed by simply Chapter 1. The gameplay feels fluid and reminds me of the classic platformers I grew up loving. Since then, the game has only improved and expanded. It is amazing to look back and see that so many years of work and dedication were put into the making of this game and the same work and dedication that comes from the community.

I am proud to have been a part of TowerClimb in my own little way and hope that it can entertain you just like it has for me. 

If I had to summarize what I enjoy about the game, the major points would be a great soundtrack and the mental challenge it gives. At the beginning of a run, you can take it slowly and space out every jump, but as the game gets more hectic and fast-paced, you really feel your mind kicking into overdrive just to make the precise movements and grabs you need to survive. TowerClimb properly has proposed a puzzle that players feel a desire to solve. Learning piece by piece lets you truly experience the game, but an active community and veterans from half a decade ago are available to help out a novice player.

I would reccomend this game to all my friends and everyone who likes a frustrating challenge that reaps a fulfilling reward.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991527956', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1650805059}
review:
[h1]Challenging.  Unforgiving but very rewarding. Fair.[/h1] The perfect mix of roguelike and platformer elements.

I like to call this game the Quake of roguelike platformers, because just like Quake it offers raw, fun and deterministic  gameplay free of any unnecessary distractions.

If you want to prove your skill and test your mettle, look no further - the game will challenge your both strategic and tactical decision making as you climb to reach the top while avoiding rabid dogs, throwing spikes at rats and taking leaps of faith to dodge magic missiles cast by the mad wizard.

Thankfully you're not entirely defenseless - you begin the journey equipped with [b]4 kinds of potions[/b] - 3 granting instant effects when used and the 4th acting as one-time revival*, that you can occasionally replenish - for a price. 

During your gameplay you will stumble upon a variety of items that will often prove [i]indispensable[/i] in advancing higher, ranging from spring boxes, spears and boomerangs, through various equipment enhancing your movement abilities to magical orbs and wands, [i]arcane steaks[/i] and even legendary weaponry!

As you climb higher, you'll get a chance to visit different sections of the tower - each with its own distinct look, set of challenges and mechanics - be it often flooded [b]conservatory[/b] inhabited by worms, piranhas and exploding seed pods, icy platforms of [b]ancient ruins[/b] with windy passages and unsettlingly long, sharp and fragile stalactites hanging as if in anticipation, [b]the heart[/b], a hellish home to lava bats that will grab any careless adventurer and hurl him into the omnipresent lava... and that's just the beginning.

And if you're feeling especially brave, you might be tempted to take a shortcut through the infamous [b]path of exile[/b] - but very few survived to tell the tale.

*The revival potion saves you only from selected kinds of deaths - if your hand slipped while climbing in a race against the clock and rapidly rising levels of lava - or trying to outrun a giant worm who will literally devour any- and everything standing between its giant fangs and yourself - you're out of luck!

Super hard, super fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979724838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1629521846}
review:
As Vinny puts it, it's Reverse Spelunky. You play a pixel man (or rather, series of ill-fated pixel men) attempting to ascend a 100-floor tower. Of course, where gravity would generally work in your favour in Spelunky, climbing UP a maze of deathtraps makes for a fairly different experience.

It's an excruciatingly hardcore game. It's permadeath, and where Spelunky gave you a health system, roughly everything in TowerClimb will eviscerate, bifurcate, detonate, devour, or melt you upon contact, whereby you had better still have a revival potion on you if you want to continue. Apparently the game is divided into chapters, but I've never made it past the first one. I get the feeling I haven't made it even halfway through the first one. That being said, the random levels make for good replay factor and the hazards change up pretty regularly as you progress. Just don't expect it to be as forgiving as Spelunky.

Only real complaint is lack of a pause function, you only get to take a breather between floors.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991559968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1697930278}
review:
TL:DR - "Towerclimb is one of the most engaging, menacing and downright tense games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. It will make you want to throw your controller across the room and then desperately reassemble it to keep playing more. It's atmosphere and music are big highlights alongside the tense gameplay."

Long form - This game is recommended for persistant, dedicated, patient players. It is *very* old school tough and it does NOT cater to people who are looking for a game with all the (cough) "features" of modern rogue-lites like constant saves, several lives,  and character building mechanics that make successive runs easier; this game gives you none of that. This is 80's-90's tough, at least when you are starting out. Then you play more, get a bit farther, learn what things to watch out for, learn how far you jump and the way you can move in the air. You begin to understand how the monsters and traps work. Then, gradually you can get to floor 8, then 10, then 19 and finally you beat chapter 1. And when you do reach the top for your first time your heart, I gauruntee you this, will feel like it is about to explode with a mix of anxiety, fear, and joy. Then your baloon ride up puts you into chapter 2. You can relax a bit at this point because you can now access chapter 2 content without having to beat the tower again. Which BTW...

**Acessing chapter 2 is done by picking-up the "2" to the right of the Tower Entrance and bringing it to the portal during the new game scene. The skull, if brought to the portal, activates Centurion Trials.**

 On the negative, a downside faced by new players is that It has *very* nuanced and subtle mechanics and "tricks" that are not laid out clearly. Almost none of these tricks are required for beating the first chapter but knowing them and using them well makes the climb to the top significantly safer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991929668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1183, 'last_played': 1664759865}
review:
TowerClimb is an action platformer that changes every time you die. The controls are solid, and at first glance, seem extremely simple. However, with enough experimentation and practice, you'll slowly realize a whole spectrum of mobility options available to you. With each technique you learn, new paths to traverse the difficult terrain will unfold before your eyes.

Although most of the story is inferred, this is a game rich with music, ambiance and theme. The slow ardous task of climbing could have made for a very dull game, but each floor offers out new and exciting challenges to overcome. Throw in some different random events and variations, and you'll be thankful for just an extra second to plan your next move.

The core themes of this game are mastery and discovery. Each set of three floors you surpass will lead you to a new "zone" which will have a different visual theme. Watch the trailer if you want to see some of those in more detail. In addition to the mechanics that must be mastered to progress through each zone, each zone has a sort of philosophical theme that you must master as a person, as well. For example, some zones test your ability to plan ahead, whereas others will test your ability to think quickly.

One thing to note is that this is a very difficult and punishing game. Normally, sessions only take less than 30 minutes. By my first 30, I had died probably 25 times. However, as you learn, you will blow through the early stages very quickly. Reaching the first and only checkpoint takes about a 30 minute session, once you've mastered the controls and concepts.

Currently, there is no way to save any progress inside of the Tower. Once you unlock the checkpoint, that's it. People have suggested a save/quit feature, and we may see it in a future patch. 

Regardless of whether another checkpoint is added or save/quit gets added, I still fully reccommend this title. There is so much to enjoy and there are tons of unlockables that take quite a bit of effort to achieve.

Easily one of the best features is the local co-op; this game is a blast if you have some friends around to play it with.

If you've read this much of my review and you're on the fence about making the purchase, just buy it. This is one of my absolutely favorite video games ever made, and I know I've been talking about it non-stop for the past three years.

review:
While this game does fit the description of a roguelike, there simply doesn't feel like there is enough variety to the content or mechanisms to make the gameplay rewarding enough for the price (especially given the alternatives).  There is no character progression (as far as I observed), no overall growth or goals (aside an album of death types to complete), and once you understand the basic jumping patterns, it all feels awkwardly sterile and repetitive.  

As a secondary complaint, the pixel-style graphics, while charming, are a bit muddy and have a fairly limited color palette, leaving a number of enemies and objects very difficult to tell apart.

The music, however, is truly excellent.

What do you get when you throw Spelunky, Kid Icarus, and Dark Souls in a blender?  TowerClimb!

7/13/16 UPDATE:  This game has only gotten better with time! Although it's criminal that more people don't love and appreciate this gem, I take solace in the fact that word-of-mouth will only continue to spread. It's just too good of a game to go unnoticed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041535097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1596950406}
review:
TowerClimb... where to start.

TowerClimb is absolutely a fantastic game, great pixel-art (which can be depixelated via settings!) amazing music and it has the most replayability you could possibly get out of a procederally generated world based video game. I originally bought the beta and I've been playing it for a little over one year and I'm still not bored of it.

Trying to set my bias aside, here are some pros and cons about TowerClimb:
Pros:
- Replayability: TowerClimb has probably the most replay value I've seen compared to most dungeon crawlers, rogue-likes and similar games. Every time you play you get different events, you discover to new areas and you die in a variety of fantastic different ways (105 different deaths to be exact).
- Aesthetic: There are a lot of pixel-art oriented games out there, especially in the genre of platforming, however TowerClimb does it quite well above and beyond the rest. Using a blend of visual effects and pixel-art you get a wonderfully crafted world with complete consistency.

Cons:
- Controls: While TowerClimb is great, I am curently at a stand-still with the controls. Even after mapping the controls to a controller--GCN controller in my case--I am still not quite happy with them. Over all you've got probably 12 different keys needed to play, for example: 3 for potions, 3 for inventory, 4 to move(possibly 5 if you re-map jump) along with the run key and item-store key. So the controls can be a bit of a mess a first, but they are re-configurable with up to 25 different profiles, so there isn't too much of a problem once you've finally settled in.

My overall score is 9/10. Controls aside, TowerClimb is too fantastic to pass up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040884867', 'num_games_owned': 2434, 'num_reviews': 901, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1649807601}
review:
[b]This game is seriously awesome.[/b] Even though it has a few rough edges as far as controller support is a bit dodgy and screen resolutions need work, it gets a total thumbs-up from me.

If you like [i]Spelunky[/i], you will certainly like this. In my opinion, it takes all the best parts of [i]Spelunky[/i] and scraps the rest - namely the ghost that rushes you through every level. [b]Plus it supports up to four player local co-op.[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Great pixel graphics, and overall ambience. I mean the mood and sounds are just really well done.
+No hand holding what-so-ever, and knowledge is certainly rewarded.
+Really addicting - 'just one more run' kind of thing.
+It is not super fast gameplay - you take your time, generally, and solve levels like a puzzle and manage your resources.
+[i]There is alot of game here.[/i] There are 2 chapters, and after you complete chapter 1 (20 floors), you can always start at chapter 2. From what I read, completing chapter 1 is many, many hours of invested gameplay.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Controller support needs some work. XBox360 wireless works, but often needs to be rebound and the digital pad does not work right.
-Graphics options are bad - it needs to make use of the whole screen better.
-Price seems high, but its worth it

[b]I am in love with this title. I actually think I like it more than [i]Spelunky[/i], which I feel bad saying.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197984756139', 'num_games_owned': 1239, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1492338365}
review:
I first played this game in 2012, when it was in beta version. Now, 3 and half years later, and with 400 deaths to learn from, I can safely say it's been one of my favorite roguelikes since.

It's got many things in its favor: the danger is everywhere, but you get plenty of ways to deal with it; the controls are smooth and fast; the different areas are all quite distinct, but also predictable enough that you should be able to learn how to face them. Perhaps the only problem is that, due to the randomized platforms, you might eventually find yourself in an "unwinnable" situation if you wasted all your jumping potions. But even that shouldn't happen once you manage your resources well.

The music and visuals are also well crafted, and the design is pretty cute. Just don't get too attached to your little guys because they will die one after the other. It is a roguelike after all.

review:
Brutally hard, and uncompromising on its design choices, but rarely (if ever) feeling 'unfair'. Dripping with otherworldly atmosphere, aided largely by an awesome low-fi soundtrack. Puzzle platforming at its finest (and deadliest). That's how I'd describe this unique little (huge!) game, but that wouldn't even come close to doing it justice.

As you might've read from other reviews, the controls take a while to get used to. You might call it the first big challenge of the game. Thankfully, you can map them however you'd like, and after a few deaths you'll begin to develop a particular instinct for it. I play on keyboard, so I can't speak to the issues people are experiencing with gamepads-- but I can say that on keyboard, the only barrier to mastery is your own skill. One of the first lessons you'll teach yourself is when best to hold the run button. The answer, unless you're very skilled, is rarely "always". Taking your time, planning your route and using all items to your advantage is the key to success.

Once you've mastered the controls, the real challenge awaits: 100 floors, no saves. That's Chapter 1, anyway. Each floor is themed to a particular 'biome', and each biome contains its own set of enemies and challenges. Scattered around the levels are various items you can use or store for later, such as jump berries or crates. The levels being largely destructable, sometimes you must use your collected arsenal to jump larger gaps, blast a path through the terrain, or kill enemies that stand between you and the exit. On top of this, special 'events' may trigger upon entering a new level. I won't spoil them, but suffice it to say you'll never quite know what to expect on the next floor!

A quick word on the graphics: What you're seeing in the screenshots is NOT how the game can look at its best! By default, for some inexplicable reason, there is a filter called 'de-pixelize' being applied. If you want the best experience, immediately toggle the 'de-pixel' setting OFF in the graphics options! I don't know quite what they were thinking when they added this, as it wasn't in the beta, but I think it makes everything look like a bad SNES emulator. The sprites were designed and work best as pixel art; the player character and various enemies you'll encounter have very minimalist sprites, but the de-pixel setting blends and smooths their edges in a way that looks quite ghastly to me. Maybe this opinion is a product of playing the beta for so long without this option, but I don't think so. I don't like the filtered look on my SNES games, and I don't like it here. It somehow manages to reduce the details, turning crisp graphics into wet goop. Don't use it, you won't miss it.

In summary:
*Challenging and rewarding gameplay
*Beautifully rendered (as long as you switch de-pixelize off)
*Incredible, moody soundtrack and effects
*Difficult to master, and may prove frustrating for more casual players, or those who struggle with platforming
*Best suited for keyboard play, but gamepad support is currently being improved based on feedback


For how long it has the potential to keep you engrossed, TowerClimb is well worth the price, and I was satisfied with my purchase even before it came to Steam and received a ton of new content!

review:
Towerclimb is a very satisfying game, the kind where it feels great to die over, and over again. Because it WILL happen, and it WILL be your fault. The object is to... climb a tower. I highly recommend this game for fans of difficult platforming roguelites, who want to be rewarded for exploration and taking risks.

review:
Towerclimb is an exceptional take on the Roguelite platformer genre. I have yet to see any that come close. This is a truly unique game, slow-cooked by a passionate pair of developers.

If you like a game that: 
- Rewards patience, but also sometimes requires you to think on your feet and move fast
- Has a simple art style, but achieves a deep sense of atmosphere
- Produces thousands of stories to tell, but none of them are scripted
- Rewards development of advanced player skills, but has simple game mechanics
- Is an enriching single-player experience, but can be experienced co-operatively as well
- Prioritizes rich and engaging gameplay at its core, but has a lovingly crafted aesthetic
- Progresses based on your in-game choices, but there is no 'right' or 'wrong' answer

Then Towerclimb just may be for you. It's for me, that much I know, and I'm happy to recommend it to anyone who takes joy in the act of engaging with a video game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965950366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1274, 'last_played': 1519266757}
review:
They have stood here forever... Many men dreampt to reach the top... Today, I am one of them.

Towerclimb is a phenomenal platformer with a handful of roguelike qualities, such as random level generation and permanent death. To reach even the end of the first chapter requires skill, dedication, patience, and let's face it: A huge helping of luck. Because you -will- fuck up. You -will- make a mistake. That mistake will most likely be your end!

But that's okay! You start with one revive potion! And not everything is out to get you! Almost everything, maybe even 99% of everything, but not completely everything! You'll start out with several supplies, like jump potions and potions that blow up blocks, and one that teleports you within a short range. You can replenish these potions by collecting Golden berries, usually placed in a precarious location, and trade them tower inhabitants such as the Witch. You can also give items to a guy who will craft stuff for you, but he'll charge you for new items that he makes and sometimes he'll give you junk. 

It's so hard to review this game without spoilers, because a lot of the fun comes with exploring the world of the towers and discovering very subtle hints as to the lore of the world. As well, discovering new items, creatures to fight, and traps to overcome can be extremely rewarding from a standpoint of "Am I skilled enough to do this?". The atmosphere is simply as beautiful as it is deadly, which is to say very. I simply can't praise this game enough, and recommend it to everyone who appreciates difficult, yet rewarding challenges.

The levels change after every 3 to 4 stages, and each has it's own unique theme. Each level has many variations to it that are possible, as well, both in design and gameplay.  It is extremely rare to have an unfairly generated level, and even those can be overcome by conserving and using your supplies at the right times. You will have to manage how many potions you have left, and you'll have to carefully consider climbing routes. Maybe instead of blowing up that block stopping you from climbing up the side of the tower, you can long jump across a gap and find a way. Maybe instead of teleporting in the Ruins, you can find a gust of wind to make you soar to the next platform. It makes you think about the safest route, and it makes you pit risk against reward. Sure, you could go for that treasure chest past the lava pit, right behind that pulsating, hatching beetle egg. But at what cost? Will the reward be worth it, or will it be just another gold berry? Well, maybe I can safely explode a wasp nest instead and get one from there. Or maybe I'll climb the side wall as far as possible and avoid that nonsense altogether, finding an alternative route. Maybe a rat will fall on my head and explode me. Maybe ???? will happen!

This game has come SO FAR since the Alpha 5 years ago, and even far from the Beta. I am super proud of Davio and Quazi for releasing this game, a game that deserves far more attention and adoration than it is receiving at the time of this writing. So, I'll leave you with this. If you love a difficult and rewarding challenge and won't run away, if you can laugh at yourself when you die, if you can accept that you will make mistakes and will learn from them for next time, if you love discovery and mystery, if you love chunky pixel art and amazing music, this game might be for you. Just two last things, eh kid? If you fall, you di... I mean you lose. And if you see your character go "?", climb quickly! Beat cheeks out of there! I can tell you that from experience... 

10/10 would be forcibly cremated again!

the tower calls…

author: {'steamid': '76561198004695599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 116065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2229, 'last_played': 1705213020}
review:
This is a game that has filled that tough platforming itch I've been trying to scratch for years. I've played a lot of platformers. Super Mario games are great, but they're always relatively easy to blow through with little difficulty, and a lot of other games just always mess up small details that makes it not quite that game I'm looking for. Then along comes TowerClimb, and everything is about as close to perfect as it can get.

Graphics:
I know there are a lot of games out there that have pixel art, but let's be honest here, they don't always do it well, and that's why they don't always look good. Davioware and Quazi really nailed the detail on their game in this category. The amount of detail put into everything is exquisite, and it really makes for some nice eye candy.

For some reason there's an option for depixelizing the game that is on by default, and I highly suggest turning that off, as the smoothness to me just doesn't look as good in my opinion. Some may like it I suppose, and that's why the option is there.

Music/sound:
This soundtrack is incredible. Once you hit chapter 2, the music hits this level of epic that just blew me away. At times I wanted to just put the controller down and just jam out to the music. Chapter 1's music is awesome as well, but it feels like it's just one level below the second chapter.

The sounds of the game are incredibly satisfying. Whether I'm slicing into a beetle, killing a dog, or dying for the 50th time, every sound is fitting, enjoyable, and adds that nice little touch to an overall great experience. All of it just feels like it was well thought out and well composed. Top notch here!

Story:

The story is interesting, deep, and definitely makes one think despite how simple it appears. You are a climber, and you are climbing a tower that many have tried to climb before. You may fail, but you may succeed. Take it from there! Yet somehow there's so much more to it than that, as this tower has some history, and it alludes to it in many different forms. It is almost akin to jumping into the world of The Labyrinth. 

Gameplay:
Take Super Mario World. Now add climbing, extra jumps, item hopping, teleporting, and weapons, and you have the controls for this game. It feels amazing to control. The controls are extremely responsive and expect you to be too. The controls are straightforward and easy to learn (with the exception of item hopping, which I suggest learning), yet take a lot of practice to master. Even after mastering the controls, you have to learn how to deal with all the different situations you encounter in the game. since this is a roguelite, there's perma-death, which means you're dead when you die. No checkpoints. No quicksaves. No ranking system to beef you up for your next journey. You start with the clothes on your back and the determination you set out with.

Seeing as how this is a roguelite, there's an expectation that this game is hard, and it is. It is incredibly hard. This game has to be learned. Rather than rote memorization, expect to know how to deal with beetles swarming you, or being dropped into a den of hounds. Or both, since there is indeed an edge of cruelty to this game. There are items to help you through all the terrors of the tower, and they can be greatly helpful to moderately helpful, ranging from gloves that help you run faster to seeds that hold explosive berries and jump berries. All these items can be stored in the inventory for later use or carried on hand ready to be used in some capacity. The items are really well thought out, and the limit on items makes one not feel too overwhelmed with useless items yet sometimes trying to figure out which items is the least useful at the time. Expect to die until you figure out how to use items wisely and be resourceful.

Summary:
Persevere and the rewards shall be bountiful, as this game really feels great to run through. Climbing up and down the towers is just a pleasure to do, and this is my personal go to game for when I want to blow off some steam. Don't expect to be good at the game to start, and don't expect to find everything quickly. This game will chop off your head, hand it to you, then make you figure out how to eat it. But when you figure out how to eat it, oh does it taste so good! It's definitely my favorite game of the year, and possibly my favorite game of all time.

Score: 10/10
