author: {'steamid': '76561198074321827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1455837184}
review:
[b][i]TowerClimb[/i][/b] is a procedurally generated platformer adventure game with roguelike elements. You play as one of many who seek to climb to the top of an ancient stone tower. The path is wrought with many obstacles, including enormous creatures, traps, and supernatural events. Along the way, you'll encounter strange characters and find useful tools to aid you on your journey. As you progress, you'll uncover a hidden lore and various side-quests in order to unlock the mysteries of the towers.

Similar to games like [i]Spelunky[/i] and [i]Just Get Through[/i], the game is split into randomized levels, each with different themes and variations to keep things challenging. Unlike [i]Spelunky[/i], however, the game is slower-paced and is much more methodical. You can't just breeze through with a Teleporter (not to knock its difficult skill ceiling). Ascending the tower is a careful process. Not all paths will get you to the exit, so planning and patience is a necessity. Because of this, the game expects the player to have skill, mastery, and knowledge of the game's finer mechanics as one mistake can cost you the whole run. Also, there are multiple environmental mechanisms that need to be mastered in order to traverse the game's later levels, similar to [i]Donkey Kong Country[/i] or [i]Super Mario[/i]. In true roguelike fashion, death means an immediate game over -- there are no checkpoints or saves (though revival potions can be bought from vendors). 

The platforming mechanics of [i]TowerClimb[/i] are unique. Climbing is simple but important: it allows you to save yourself from falling to your death, and you can even climb across ceilings and the bottoms of platforms. Jumping is interesting in this game as you start with a single limited leap. However, items like potions or special berries can allow you to jump multiple times in succession. Even finer skills of the game allow you to throw items downward to give yourself a boost when there's no other solution. Destructive items double as weapons against enemies and erasers to change the generated terrain. There's other items that modify your abilities, but they aren't necessarily needed in order to succeed. Everything about [i]TowerClimb[/i]'s gameplay shows a great deal of polish, which is remarkable considering the small development team of two. 

My favorite thing about the game is its atmosphere. I'm reminded of [i]Risk of Rain[/i], where your avatar is only a few pixels tall, and everything else is incredibly vast. It adds this great sense of mystery and wonder to the game. Even from the beginning, as you enter the tower, you face a looming ominous portal bathing you in an intense violet light. On the ground floor, it's apparent that the path ahead won't be easy, even on the first level. Giant rats and hounds look truly monstrous in comparison to you, and the creatures only get creepier as you climb higher. Environmental hazards can be just as deadly. Just about anything can happen in this tower: from lava bursting out of the ground to entire levels filled with water. Compared to how gigantic everything is, you can't help but feel a sense of humility. Exploring the tower can make you feel almost insignificant, and you're reminded of just how fragile you are when braving the many dangers that surround you.

Aesthetically, the game is done in a pixelated art style. It uses low-resolution graphics infused with hardware accelerated lighting effects and rendering capabilities, and gameplay runs at 60 FPS. You can choose to play the game with its raw pixel art or with a blended filter that somehow manages to look even more retro. However, the soundtrack really steals the show. The game features more than 80 dark and foreboding tracks. It reminds me of RPGs from the 90's on consoles like the SNES or the Sega Genesis. It definitely makes your quest feel epic, and I can't imagine playing this game while listening to something else.

As much as I love this game, it definitely isn't perfect. The game doesn't have a tutorial, so players might have a hard time mastering the basics in just a couple of runs. It's a pretty difficult game that will offer challenges to players of all skill levels. It feels awkward to play the game with just a keyboard, so I would definitely recommend using a gamepad. Graphically, I know there are lots of players out there who are tired of the pixelated art that's found in many other indie games. Sometimes, items and hazards aren't easily recognizable and can cause some frustrating ends to runs. However, the development team is incredibly dedicated and is open-minded to suggestions and ways to improve the game.

[i]TowerClimb[/i] serves as a testament to how amazing indie games can be. It started as a humble demo on GameJolt and was Greenlit on Steam in 2012. It's taken Davioware and Quazi [b]6[/b] whole years to develop and polish the game. They didn't put it on Kickstarter or crowdfund the game. Just by playing it, you can feel how much love and labor was invested into this project. $15.00 may feel like a little steep of a price for this game, but I feel that they've definitely earned it after creating such an artistic masterpiece. This game is a great little reminder of how much beauty and depth can be found in unassuming simple things.

[b]TL; DR:[/b] For fans of platformers, roguelikes, and good games.

review:
I've been playing this game since its early beta versions, and it's honestly one of the best purchases I've made.
If you like 'roguelike' platformers, or just challenging platformers at all, you'll definitely want to check this one out.

It's incredibly challenging, but always in a fair way. Every run is an intense experience, and the higher you get into the tower, the better it gets. When you get to a new place, way up in the tower, that you've never been to before, you're just swarmed with so many different emotions that it's hard to describe. The amazement of seeing the new place, the fear of dying and having to start all over again, and the sense of accomplishment, all at once, makes for an unforgettable experience.

The mechanics are solid, altough it can be pretty difficult to get the hang of the controls for new players.
Once you learn the basics, though, you're gonna have insane ammounts of fun.

The atmosphere and soundtrack are also spot on, and make the experience even better.

If you like a good challenge, do yourself a favor, and give this game a try. I guarantee you're not gonna regret it.

review:
Towerclimb is the best game I've ever played. That's what I still think after playing it for more than 2 years. I've never played a game as challenging and rewarding as towerclimb. When I first starting playing, I thought I'd never beat chapter 1, but when I finally did, I was ecstatic. I thought I was a pro, who has conquered towerclimb and all the challenges it has to offer. Then the centurial trials appeared. 100 floors of pure insanity... I knew I'd never beat it. "That's just for fun, right? People aren't actually expected to beat this." Hundreds of deaths and hundreds of hours later, I finally reached floor 101. I beat the trials. It was the most amazing gaming experience I've ever had. Being on floor 90 and knowing that I can lose it all with one tiny misstep is the most scary feeling I've experienced in any game. Not even a game like dead space could keep me continuously on-edge like that. 

Towerclimb is an emotional rollercoaster that can bring you intense feelings of fear, frustration, happiness, excitement, etc., and the music is a big part of that. The music fits the atmosphere and scenarios perfectly. In the plant-controlled observatory, the music feels as if it's alive, and creeping up on you. In the cold, icey ruins, you can hear just how frigid it is, and you can almost feel the pain from the cold air brushing against you. In the volcanic heart, you can feel the magma boiling beneath your feet, ready to burst any minute. The industrial segmentation plant makes you feel like you're surrounded by technology and traps that are prepared to kill you whenever you get near. Giant worm fights are backed with intense music that really make you feel helpless. But once you defeat it, you are rewarded with absolute silence to contemplate the victory you have earned.

Discovery is another big point of towerclimb. The game starts with no tutorial, and at first I thought it was a simple game, but I soon started to uncover the layers of complexity by just... playing. I didn't need to look at a wiki or anything like that. Some items took me a long time to find a use for them. I used to think the golden greaves were useless because they made me so fast that it was impossible to control. But eventually, after getting used them, I realized they are the most useful item in the game.

When I first found the bitchbane, and the game told me a quest has started, I knew I was going on an adventure, in real life. Anytime I wasn't playing towerclimb, I'd try to think about what the next step could be so I could try it out when I got home. For months, I didn't know what to do, until I discovered you can use the bitchbane to kill a giant worm to get the next sword in the quest. Then use that sword to get another sword. And finally get the last one, the Ascender. Keep in mind, at this point I already thought I had known everything that was in this game. Now here's 3 new items. I started getting more handy with their own individual uses, and eventually brought the ascender to the 101st floor to fully complete the quest.

2 years later, I still have one more quest to complete, and I try at least once a week to beat it. My experience with towerclimb still hasn't ended...

review:
I've played a lot of Towerclimb over the past few years - the various earlier beta versions of it, at least - and if you're a fan of Spelunky or other similar murder-maze platformers, then this is well worth buying. Towerclimb leans a bit closer towards the rouguelike side of things - rather than rely entirely on your twitch platforming skills (which WILL be tested), you're asked to plan and assemble an inventory of tools and potions to help you survive, and yes, you can find yourself backed into a corner if you didn't keep enough in reserve to plan for emergencies.

The SNES-era graphics work surprisingly well, with a lot of shader and bloom effects to flesh out the otherwise straightforward pixel look. The soundtrack especially is excellent. Lots of mysterious, dark, brooding melodies that help drive you on while helping to establish a brooding, oppressive atmosphere. The tower is not a friendly place.

Towerclimb is a very long and very replayable game. A single playthrough will take you through dozens of randomly generated floors, and due to the way that hazards and traps can interact with each other (ala Spelunky), you can end up in some very chaotic situations that require quick thinking to work your way out of. You'll see a lot of death screens before you get anywhere near the end of this, but it's very satisfying every time you clear a new zone.

Now, back into the tower - I've got a few new deaths to meet!
